Lots of tart cherry and raw cocoa powder. The beginnings of a bad bottle for sure, but it was fresh enough to be acceptable. I wouldn't recommend trading for this year's batch since there have been way too many bad bottles.  2014 version, bottled on 9/16/14, 14.4% ABV. This bottle was not as sweet as the 2013 version. Also had a bottle dated 10/24/14, 13.8% ABV. This one seemed a bit more or a bourbon bite.  2013 version, bottled on 8/29/13, 14.9% ABV. Cellared for roughly 2 years. Pours black with a small sized brown head. Smells of mostly cocoa and bourbon. The taste follows closely starting with cocoa, some vanilla and molasses, then ending with oak and bourbon. Great intensity and flavor profile. No noticeable alcohol in the taste but some warming. Thick and luscious mouthfeel with lower carbonation. Like a bourbon chocolate dessert. Aged very well.
Lives up to the hype

2016  Appearance: An almost black pour with reddish tint. Dark khaki, half finger width head.  Aroma: Vanilla, cherry, bourbon and oaky  Taste: Heavy bourbon, rich cherry, chocolate, oak  Mouthfeel: Thick, rich, syrupy, minimal carbonation.  Overall: Best imperial stout that I have ever had, in fact, best beer that I have ever had. An amazing experience. I can't get enough. The more I have, the more flavors I discover. This is an extremely complex flavor composition.  *I still love the 2012 BCBS the most.

I loved this beer more than I have loved any woman. More than the fat kid loves cake. More than I love cake. I am the fat kid. I love this beer so much that I married it. It was rich, it was amazing, I had to change my undies after this beer. Even the dos Equis guy prefers this beer.

A 1 pint .9 fl oz (500ml) bottle with a bottled on date of 22nd October 2015, poured into a snifter glass.  Appearance: Poured an extremely dark dark brown colour with a reddish hue on the sides. Dark tanned head was very thin and did not last long and there was some thin spotty lacing.  Aroma: Rich rich aromas full of bourbon, oak, caramel, salted chocolate and vanilla.  Taste: Much like the aromas it was full of bourbon, oak, caramel, salted chocolate and vanilla. Stunning, heavenly goodness.  Mouthfeel: Full bodied, thick motor oil like richness. Low carbonation. Nice light burn as it goes down.  Overall: Wow, this was amazing… a brilliant sipper. Even drinking it 3 months in, aromas, taste and feel were already wonderful. It should develop more complexity with a year or two of aging, which is what I’m going to do with the rest of my bottles.

Consistently one of the best barrel aged beers available. Every year I have tried has been excellent. I prefer my barrel aged beers with coffe, but for a non adjunct barrel aged stout this does not disappoint

16.9 oz. bottle into a snifter  A - Beer pours an opaque black color with no visible carbonation. Head is non-existent after a slight fizziness erupted on top, even with a hard pour. Looking at this beer is like looking into the depths of space if space didn't have any stars. Slight motor oil resemblance right around the top edges where the beer meets the glass (surface tension area). 3.75/5  S - Aroma is heavily dominated by vanilla, bourbon, and oak. Very deep dark malty aroma that features ultra dark chocolate and a hint of espresso. The aroma is very heavy and syrupy, like straight molasses. Very grainy and earthy overall, but quite sweet. 4.5/5  T - Vanilla and toffee sweetness hit my palate right away with a quick transition into the oak and bourbon notes. Quite a bit of char and smoke go along with the oak and bourbon. Leather, molasses and vanilla dominate the middle of the tasting before a subtle and slow transition to a deep roasted espresso and ultra dark chocolate finish. 4.5/5  M - Very rich, heavy, creamy, and syrupy. Sticky throughout the entire profile. Carbonation tickle on the very front of the beer. Warming sensation on the back of the palate and the throat upon swallowing. 4.5/5  O - One word...wow... Other than there being no head whatsoever, this beer is very hard to beat and is an explosion of flavors. No flavor is subtle here. They all stand out on their own at some point or another and make themselves known. 4.5/5

Pours the dark black of long used motor oil and nearly as viscous, but I got very little head from my pour. Smell is mostly of bourbon with hints of oak and vanilla. Taste is of bourbon, vanilla, caramel, chocolate, but is slightly unbalanced by being a tad on the sweet side. Mouthfeel is excellent, not too much or little carbonation, not too sticky despite the sweetness. Overall this is an excellent beer, not the best of the barrel aged stouts that I've had, but it's close to the top of the pack. Can't wait to see what cellar aging does to the beer.

poured this into a snifter and it is jet black, it gave a chocolate 1 inch head and it went away quickly.in the smell you get vanilla, chocolate bourbon, and a nutty scent. the taste is bourbon heavy up front and you get the vanilla, chocolate, raisins, in the back. the brew is thick and syrupy. overall it is boozy and full of flavor and i cant wait to see how it gets 6 months from now.

2015 on tap at BC's Pizza & Beer and Das Bierhaus  A: Pours dark brown, basically black, with a rich brown head that settles to a thin layer and laces lightly.  S: Molasses and dark sugar up front, smooth bourbon, vanilla, toffee, a little roasted malt, hints of chocolate and coffee, and a touch of alcohol.  T: Vanilla, smooth bourbon, a little toasted coconut, molasses and brown sugar, roasted malt, a little coffee, faint chocolate, maybe a bit spicy, and a touch of alcohol on the finish.  M: Sticky full body, mild carbonation, velvety smooth with a little warmth on the finish.  O: This beer has impressed me more each time I try it. I wish a little more of the roasty character came through, but still a very enjoyable sipper.
Very good, but kind of a letdown. DFH worldwide stout is about the same IMHO.

2015 on draft pours black, faint reddish tones. Paper thin ring of tan head remains.  Smells of the bourbon, that's about it. Fairly mild though and not too boozy. Thick, thick body with taste following the nose. Some vanilla shows up later followed by some boozy warming, but it's still smooth. Finishes really clean with exceptionally balanced bitterness.  Overall, I don't have a long bourbon barrel pedigree, but this is definitely one of the best examples of the style I've ever tried.

pours jet black with a thin head.  smells like bourbon and chocolate, heavy bourbon.  taste is full of bourbon. some chocolate and definitely coffee bitterness at the end.  overall it's certainly barrel aged and full of bourbon flavor. not sure if i like the overwhelming bourbon flavor. i see this being much better with age.  gets much better when it warms!

In a snifter. Dark, dark brown with a thin dark tan head. Great bourbon smell with oak, vanilla, and some roasted malt. Beautiful taste. Bourbon of course, with vanilla, oak, dark bread, coffee, and chocolate. The malt and the booze is well-balanced. Nice warming at the end with a chocolate finish. Not overly sweet. Full bodied but also with a silky smooth feel. Hard to imagine a better imperial stout.
Breath taking
I wish this beer wasn't so damn delicious, but it is...and is my gold standard for imperial stouts. Vanilla, bourbon boozy goodness. Glad I've got a few cases, because these only get better with age.

This was hard to get, but totally worth it. Payed like 25 dlls here in Mexico. Pours deep black with a tan foam head. Aroma is great, bourbon, malts, chocolate, coffee, no hops. Taste is awesome, rich, complex, roasty, lots of bourbon and wood. Bold body, low carbonation. Excellent beer.

Look: Very dark, pours thick, not much light escapes this beer  Smell: bourbon, vanilla, carmel, coffee, chocolate  Taste: amazingly well balanced for such a bourbon forward beer. very smooth. hides the 13.7% better than any other I've tried. aftertaste very smooth  Feel: great sipper, nice thick mouth feel  Overall: doesn't get much better. i don't think a perfect score exists, just in principle, but this beer is as close as it gets. definitely worth seeking out and stocking up on

Look: Pours thick and dark. Some subtle microfizzys on top that appear to be doing their own unique cadence to edge of the glass from the center. Tilting the beer slightly 45 degrees and pulling it back to 90 degrees shows this beer is thick, making the palate water at the site of it.  Smell: A mature mix of vanilla, banana, bourbon, coffee, chocolate , burnt sugar and oak.  Taste: Follows the smell. A decadent delicious brew that is the best sipper I've had in a while. The alcohol is masked great . An explosion of all of the above smells hits the taste buds for a perfectly mixed brew.  Feel: Savory. I'm enjoying this like a fine wine more than a beer the way I'm sipping here. Very pleasant on the mouth.  Overall: I feel this is a near perfect beer.
Beautiful. Chocolate malt, and bourbon, bourbon, bourbon. So wonderfully complex.

Damn. I hate to roll with the hype but this beer exceeds it for me.  Beautiful deep black color with tiny red/brown head, little carbonation. Smells like chocolate and caramel around a campfire. Flavor is bourbon, maple, chocolate, coconut and and almonds. The beer glides over the tongue in an oil slick bliss.  Jesus Christ this beer is good.
Wow, intense flavored: coffee, dark chocolate, bourbon. Very long finish.

I awoke early on Black Friday to get this beer, so it better be good. As usual, I drank too much on Thanksgiving, so rising early on Black Friday isn't at the top of my to do list...until this year.  Glass: tulip  Setting: cold winter night, back porch, toasty fire  Demeanor (mine): Ready, willing, able, but just a little intimidated. Are my expectations too high?  It's showtime. Finally.  The bottle is a work of art in and of itself. The first sign of the liquid brings pure joy. It's dark. Which reminds me of a line from Airplanes: "I like my beer the way I like my . . ." Oh wait, never mind. It's not only dark; it's also rich. Not much head, but what is there is darker than most beers! So high in alcohol content that is has legs like a good distilled spirit.  Smells and tastes of molasses, baked cherries, vanilla, raisins, figs, dates, plus a little smoke and a little oak. Other than that, pretty basic stuff.

Pours dark. Heavenly aroma- sorry I can't be more descriptive, but I was a few in. Surprisingly minimal heat. Slightly sweet (we did the 2014 and 2015 at a late 2015 tasting). Complexity certainly increased with age. Solid feel. One (two) of the more delicious darks I've ever had.

My first time. Fantastic brew. Dated 11/11/2015. Revisiting 8/26/2019 on draft at Ron’s Corner Tavern. Not sure what year. Dark and rich as they come. The aroma in a league of its own. The taste is rich of molasses, brown sugar and dark fruit. The mouthfeel has a bite like heat. Smooth. Overall this is super fine.

I get it. This is a very special beer but it's overrated for all the hype and stress it creates. Maybe I'll sell the bottle on ebay for the same price I bought it for.  Look: I gave it a heavy pour at around 65 degrees and got a tiny head that dissipated very quickly. Sign of a very high booze content. Smell: Chocolate, Vanilla, Coffee, dark fruits. A little bit of heat from the booze. Taste: Chocolate, vanilla, coffee, dark fruits. Feel: Covers your entire mouth and leaves you with a nice burning thanks to the booze. Definitely a sipper. Overall: I like bourbon and I like beer. I like this beer but I regret the things I had to do to get it... I will never be clean again... I've got another bottle in the cellar and I'll sit on it for year or two.

L: Pours a beautiful midnight black with a thin cappuccino color head. You can tell the alcohol content is quite high just by looking at this pour.  S: I could smell this all day. Huge bourbon aroma. Lots of vanilla, caramel, maybe a little coffee, and dark roasted malts. Smells sweet and boozy and delicious.  T: Pure roasted malts with heaviness notes of bourbon and vanilla. Quite well balanced in terms of its alcohol content. Unlike some other bottles, I'm getting no sign of infection. Classic bourbon barrle-aged stout.  F: Thin and viscous. Nice warming quality from the alcohol as it goes down. Vanilla and bourbon all throughout the mouth.  O: Classic beer. It's a go-to for me whenever I can find it. It's warming and decadent, and goes perfectly with a cold winter day.

Nice sweet bourbon w/ subtle dark fruit (chocolate covered cherry) in the entry. Big cooked caramel follows right behind. Smokiness and ash are prominent but not overpowering. Sweet bourbon is a nice firm component without taking over the whole beer. Caramel rolls in to nice chocolaty booze. The bourbon also gives off some nuanced maple tones. Nice, earthy soft bitterness in the finish. The carbonation combined with the hops gives the beer a minute bite. Cereal grains linger on the tongue after the hops and carbo die off. A super complex beer. First time having it. Very impressed. Probably one of the few AB InBev products I will consume. If you can get it, grab a bottle... or three.  For this beer (bottled 9/15, drank 1/16) the hops, carb, and booze are touch bitey/young. I can't wait to have this beer in another year!

Split this with my brother....  Man oh man. Aromas of bourbon and oak. Flavors of bourbon, brown sugar, stewed/dried plums, moist tobacco, cola, vanilla, toffee. It was thick and syrupy and quite possibly one of the best stouts I have ever had (definitely the best bourbon stout!).  In short...amazing!

Probably one of the best stouts (and beers) I've had, ever. Pours really nicely with a thin head that settles into some thin lacing. The aroma is just amazing. Rum raisin, chocolate, malt, brunt caramel, and dark fruits all come into mind. It doesn't smell "boozy" but you know when you smell it that there's alcohol in it. The taste and texture are sublime. Dark chocolate and fruit mix and mingle together very nicely on the palette and ends in a sweet then bitter note that makes for an all-over balanced tasting experience. The texture is thick, even for a stout and coats the tongue very nicely. High viscosity that remains through each sip. Ready to enjoy out of the bottle...but I will be cellaring the remaining bottles I have left.
2015 14.3% ABV Imperial Stouts are not my cup of tea but this is a really good one.

2015 vintage. Poured from its new bottle into a tulip glass, and out comes a beer that resembles thick motor. A nice mocha, tan ring of bubbles lasts as I drink. The aroma is fantastic; bourbon, vanilla, oak, char, chocolate, maybe some maple, and some dark fruit. Taste is incredibly decadent, and much of that comes from its velvety mouthfeel. The beer is excellent, bourbon, vanilla, it definitely has some sweetness. It's a little hot from the booze, but at 13.7%, not surprising. Warming on the way down. This is a world class beer, and I can't wait to see how it ages over the next few years.
Dark black, almost no head (light pour).  Smells STRONGLY of bourbon, charred barrel, smoke. Tastes like im sipping on chocolatey bourbon. Smooth, but a bit of alcohol as well.
I must have gotten a bad batch. I doubt they care or will do anything. Mine was infected, tasted sour and had a funk. I sadly paid 20 for this because it was hard to get in my area. Never again.

This "beer" is an experience. This is my first year having BCBS, and I'm into my second bottle. L: looks like you want to drink it. Opaque black, small tan head, slight oil on top once head fades. S: black cherry, oak, chocolate, booze, vanilla, sugar. T: sweet, dark liquid of the gods, leads to a strong cherry flavor, with dark malt chocolate backdrop, not upfront like many imp stouts. Boozy warmth leads to a vanilla, oak and crisp dry finish, possible hop bitterness here, and bitterness from roasted malt. Incredible balance of flavors comes as an amalgamation of the most decadent flavors in life. F: Surprisingly, this beer isn't "hot" for a 14%, is simply a pleasant boozy warm. Very light carbonation, as with many BA beers. Not chewy thick, yet not a thin feeling beer, very medium bodied, and drinkable as far as imperial stouts go. O: a memorable beer, truly decadent. This should send shivers down the spine of any beer/bourbon lover.

2013 bottle. Pours a deep dark brown/black...light tinge of amber around the edges. Light tan head which fades. Rich aroma of leather, sweet cherry, vanilla, cacao. Full smooth flavor, light bittersweet coffee at the end...delicious beer, quite well rounded. A tinge of hot alcohol, but not overwhelming. Awaiting tasting the newest batch!

Had on-tap at the 'Z' bar in State College, PA. Poured into a snifter.  L: Pours a thick dark brown... nearly black with 2 fingers of dense brownish head.  S: Complexity incarnate... oak and vanilla, bourbon and chocolate, booze... and possibly angel tears.  T/F: Taste follows smell remarkably well. Charred malts with dark fruits, chocolate, and vanilla. Bourbon and oak... boozy yet strikingly smooth and creamy. Warming and the flavor gets even more robust as it warms up to room temperature.  O: I know it's an Inbev product... but this is a spectacular beer. (and hey, they didn't louse it up!). A rare treat whenever you can find it on-tap and still one of the standard bearers for the style. Definitely one to enjoy whenever you can catch a glimpse.

pours ink , no head. good legs (alcohol)  good bourbon aroma. hints of dark brown sugar, vanilla,cinnamin,rich chocolate.  elegant flavors all melded together, layeres of chocolate and bourbon and spices for a great balance.not at all edgy.  creamy felon sides of mouth.dense.good warming from alcohol, not over the top.  great now, and of course with age, so i'm doing both.

Truly one of the best Imp Stouts out there. Best if aged for at least a year.  Pours pitch black with a thick opaque head. Smells of bourbon and roasty goodness. Tastes like bourbon, booze, coffee, chocolate. I prefer it to the coffee version.

L: Pitch black; light does not penetrate next to the bulb; creamy dark brown head S: Molasses; fig; prune; burnt sugar; graham cracker; liquorice; T: starts sweet, tunrs sour and ends bitter; burnt sugar; chickory; slight chocolate; hoppy spiciness in the finish; F: thick; little burn at end O: A little sweet and not as boubon or vanilla flavours as past years; spicy finish hangs around a lot more too;

Let me paint the picture. New Year's Eve... girlfriend runs into 7/11 for dip for her veggie plate. Hm. An innocuous liquor store next door, might as well pop in. Right as I walk into this not at all craft beer liquor store there is a open case of BCBS, heard it's pretty good, was $10 a bottle so I picked up 1 to drink and 1 to cellar.  Needless to say both were drank as I made everyone there try and everyone was as impressed as I was. I went back and got 4 to cellar...unless I feel like drinking heaven in a glass before then.
Outvof a 17 oz bottle. Heavenly beer! So well balanced, subtle burbon/ run flavor with a nice middle of vanilla and chocolale. By far one of the best beers I have had. Worthy of the search.

Absolutely wonderful this is the definition that you would find next to bourbon barrel stout! L: pitch dark as in blackhole dark with almost zero head S: quality rich Bourbon smell with hints oif caramel T: sweet heavenly bourbon and smokey vanilla all infused into an amazing single taste F: I can't say enough about how smooth and easy drinking this beer is The first thought that I had was you can take me now my life is complete
Wow. Just wow. It's not a beer , it's a work of art. Great mouth feel and aroma. Don't think I'll be sharing this with company.

Description: Darth Vader dressed in a ninja suit dark black appearance. Looks silky as it pours and with absolutely no head. Smell is bourbon foremost (shocker) followed by wood/oak and some sort of a dark fruit (grape, raisin, maybe even a hint of raspberry) and a touch of vanilla. Taste is similar to the smell, as bourbon takes center stage with some dark fruit acidity behind it. It's a roasty flavor without any discernible sweetness aside from the bourbon. The finish leaves a noticeable smoky, woody flavor as it goes down. The feel is rich and velvety and this one coats the mouth without being syrupy.  Suggested food pairing: Bacon wrapped shrimp or a juicy beef brisket  If you like this beer then you should also try: Ten FIDY  Overall: 4.75 (This beer is excellent and I would definitely drink it again) This was my first foray into the Bourbon County lineup and it didn't disappoint. It wasn't quite as bourbony as I expected which I actually think was a good thing as it should some more flavor complexity and wasn't one-note. Hides the alcohol well for as high an ABV beer as this is. In short, a great beer that lived up to expectations. All the hubbub is justified and this is one to seek out.

-2015. Enjoyed in a snifter. Bot. 21oct15. Consumed 12.25.15. Warmed to recommended drinking temp by style.  A: A dark viscose pour produces a darken cherry-mocha capping of 0.5inches with a very audible sense, fizzling to a rather quick demise and patchy covering.  S: Boozy bourbon and chocolate mingle in harmony with a soothing sense of campfire minerality and charred woodiness. Fresh coffee roast is abundant, fresh, wet, silky dark aroma, with some dark fruit of plums and black cherries about. The strength and retention rate is is very nice and lingering.  T: Thick chocolate slurry, with a big bourbon flair and campfire minerality. The coffee roast is oily, wet, and fresh and of the darkest level of intensity, just the way a real coffee drinker likes it. Spicy dark fruit and liquor, roasted barley with hints of burnt brown sugar, caramel-vanilla and scorched barrel woodiness. Roasted pine and spicy hops close things out.  M: The mouthful is creamy and viscose, thick chocolate-barley, that sits heavily on the tongue with a roasted bitterness that glows on the inner cheeks. Heavenly coffee roast feel that lingers on long after the swallow.  O: After several fruitless years of searching i was able to secure a bottle and received one for x-mas. The price tag ($20) and wait was well worth it in the end. A lot of hype surrounds this beer and rightfully so. I rarely give out 5's, but in the end the flavor, intensity, coffee aspect, bourbon flair, and thick viscose mouthful and nature was so overwhelming and perfect in execution, i do not think the human tongue could detect any minor improvements if they could possibly be made. Just like you can't make a beer any hoppier then the tongue can distinguish or beyond the means of alpha acid saturation, i believe you can't make a bourbon barrel aged stout any more bigger, bolder with such a refined drinkability nature as this one. As everyone has their own individual tastes, this is just my personal opinion. This was highly polished with the 14.3% feeling perfect here adding dark and beautiful alcohol tones to the mix. I thought about aging one, but think the late fresh coffee additions after barrel aging would mellow, and this is what makes this beer such a standout, not the base beer, but the barrel aging technique and cold coffee infusion and care that goes into this production and aging that makes it worthy of seeking out and waiting in lines.

I'm at a lost on what to say. Do I comment on how sweet it smells out of the bottle? Or how smooth it is despite the 13.7% abv? Or maybe how it 's straight up darkness in a bottle? Whichever route, it is pretty damn solid. I got lucky to find a few bottles in the wild and glad I snapped them up. I an only imagine the potential of how they will be like when they age a bit. If you can find one, worth the plunge if nothing else, just to see what everyone is raving about.
Looks like motor oil but tastes like figs. There is a great noticeable bourbon taste. It all just blends really well. I got two more for aging and we will see how that goes.
Wow. Having this on tap and it's even more incredible.

This is the 2015 version which is 14.3%. Throwing it down New Years Eve 2015.....  Pours black with minimal head, which lasts about 15 seconds. Lacing is very minimal, sticks around.  Smells of bourbon first....bourbon 2nd, with some chocolate and malt... - Bourbon, chocolate, roasted malts, licorice, and booze  Taste - This is where the bourbon might take 2nd to the chocolate. A real nice flavor.  Definitely feel and taste the bourbon. It goes down pretty easy, which is impressive considering the 14.3%. Medium Body AT BEST.  Overall: I'm glad I got it. It was $9.29 for 22 ounces. Probably won't get it again but only because there are tons of other Bourbon stouts waiting to be had...

Bought my first bottle of 2015 BCBS and couldn't help but drink it rather than age it. It smells nice of roasted malt and vanilla bean. Taste was boozy, malty, tasted notes of raisin, coffee, and chocolate. Super syrupy which fits the style but is not my favorite mouthfeel. I'm glad I tried it, wouldn't go out of my way for it most likely, but would buy again if convenient (which is not common for this I understand).

vileplume's "cut the shit" review on bcbs.   this is how a bourbon barrel aged imperial stout should taste.  bourbon. stout. thick. alcohol. sweet. balance.  waited out in the cold every year for this beer, will continue to do so as there's nothing like it in the world. many imitations, none quite make the grade.

L - Jet black  S - Amazing. Smells like bourbon and chocolate.  T - Solid bourbon and tons of chocolate. Alcohol is present but enjoyable. What you would expect from BCBS.  F - Coats the pallet nicely.  O - It's Bourbon County. Find it. Drink it. Enjoy it.
Wonderful beer al around, wish I had taken tasting notes

the 2015 edition in a 16.9 bottle and poured into a white wine glass at family house, look was a dark dark pure black smells of bourbon cocoa and lots of vanilla very little head, tastes of cocoa an vanilla brown sugar and chocolate, the 14% abv is prominent. Great taste but is something the average beer drinker will need to work towards.

Before it opens up the overwhelming taste is chocolate after some time in the glass the taste is much more complex with many aspects of the bourbon barrels. There is a maple roasted nut aspect to this stout as well. The feel is thick, rich and chewy. This beer is very hedonistic!
2015 - fresh

Written from notes when I had this on Christmas. My first time ever drinking this beer; 16.9 ounce bottle from the 2015 release, with bottling date of October 1st, 2015. Pours with much glug-glug-glugging noise into my tulip-type glass.  The appearance of this beer is... black. Like not just really dark brown, but pitch black. Even the foam on top (which fizzes loudly at first before shrinking to a ring around the outside and a few traces) is pretty dark brown. My little LED flashlight can't penetrate this beer's darkness at all. The foam fizzing away to almost nothing so fast is a bit odd, but otherwise this looks really nice.  Smells sweet, a bit vanilla-ish, and sometimes I pick up on something a bit nutty or woody? Certainly smells different from other stouts I've had, but smells very good. After drinking a bit, I'm picking up a bit more stouty roastiness in the smell. And as a random side-note, apparently bugs LOVE the smell of Bourbon County Stout -- I had to swat three little fruit flies that I wasn't aware were in the room shortly after I started drinking it, as they had started to hover around the glass (and still-partially-full bottle) and I really didn't want to end up drinking some bugs if they decided to dive-bomb it.  Taste... wow! Just a little sip and I got some definite woody/nutty, sweetness, a bit of vanilla, and then a really nice roasty/chocolate/coffee blending together at the end. Burps are like a chocolate milkshake almost immediately after drinking any of this. There's so much going on that I'm having a hard time describing it all -- something about my second sip really reminded me of pecan pie, for example, and I got just a hint of alcohol in there, too. Something reminds me of maple syrup, too. This is by far the sweetest, chocolatiest stout I've ever had! Actually, this is at least as good as the image of "what a big barrel-aged stout will taste like" I had in my mind before drinking one, probably better actually. For literally being better than I could even imagine, the taste of this beer earns my first-ever 5/5 score on here.  Definitely feels thicker than most beers I've had. Okay, probably thicker than *all* beers I've had! Even a little sip feels pretty substantial, yet it tastes so good that more than a little sip works too. The alcohol is more noticeable in the mouthfeel than anywhere else, with a bit of warmth the first couple times the beer touches your lips and some definite stomach-warming going on, but for a whopping 13.7% ABV it's almost completely hidden -- I've had 7-8% ABV beers that had more perceived alcohol.  I was actually afraid I'd not like this beer, if you can believe that; I'd never had bourbon or any bourbon-barrel-aged stouts before, and I wasn't sure if any beer could ever live up to the reputation that a beer like this one has (even for someone who doesn't really buy into "hype.") Now I'm glad I grabbed three bottles when I had the chance -- though two will be shared with family or friends (good Christmas present, huh?), I'll still get to have some of this beer again without having to wait until next Thanksgiving!!  Absolutely DOES live up to its reputation. This is really, really good stuff.
This year's is so very good. Congratulations for job well done. I salute you! !!
2015 release is smooth immediately. Most need some time to mellow, this is great immediately. Can;t wait to try in with some more time.

Now I know what the fuss is all about. Goose Island has done a great job with this beer. All I've heard is that this brew sets the standard for BA beers. It is the best BA I've had. I'm glad I have more. Super easy drinking, a little boozy but it should be expected. I highly recommend trying one or two of these. I have a 2014 and 3 more 2015's . I'm looking forward to trying each of them.
DELICIOUS and INCREDIBLE. After the first sip, it became one of my top 5 favorite beers, easy
Wow. I will look for this to buy again.
what can i say that somebody else hasnt. This is a wonderful beer. I don't care who owns or produces it; the more that is available the better for everybody else.

As the originator of barrel aged stouts, BCBS continues to remain supreme among the strong cohort of russian imperial stouts. 2015 is just as superb as past years. I am thinking about experimenting an cold pressing coffee to make BCBCS with 10% coffee and 90% original stout. Fresh is a little too hot for my liking similarly to fresh Deschutes' The Abyss.
Let this beer warm a bit (50F). Gets a more full taste. Very boozy with definite Bourbon notes. Smoky and deep sweetness that will keep you sipping this fine crafted brew!

Pours a jet black motor oil consistency that shows almost no head, but what is there is a dark brown sugar color. Aroma is amazing with bourbon, vanilla, smoke, bittersweet chocolate, and dark fruits. Taste follows with chocolate, bittersweet chocolate, vanilla, oak, dark fruit, smoke, and barrel character, just an amazing melange of harmonious flavors. Mouthfeel is oily, silky, and so super smooth and creamy. Overall, an excellent beer and one I'm glad I got to try, because it is one of the best I've had.
Look- black/oil like consistency Taste- lots of Bourbon, Carmel,vanilla, smoke Aroma-Bourbon,smoke,vanilla

Appearance is black with clear mahogany edges and a quickly receding soft mocha fizz that leaves clear legs on the glass.  On both the nose and the palate I get very well dialed in and balanced notes of chocolate, raisin, maple and smoky nutty oak with bourbon that mellows as it warms. It continues to develop as you dig into it, and the complexity makes it apparent how expertly crafted this is, with a deft, balancing touch allowing plenty of room for char, nougat, granola, vanilla, Tootsie Roll, and sweet toffee. As it warms and on the finish, coconut, date, and even hints of dry red wine grapes come in.  The nose hints at a little more heat than actually translates on the palate, which is a nice, comforting surprise. Feel is thick but smooth, almost sticky, but mostly velvety, and actually reducing in heft the longer you sit with it.  I have had a wide variety of vintages at this point, both fresh and at different points in their cellar life cycles, and with the exception of a 2015 draft that potentially had early signs of infection, Bourbon County Brand Stout is an astonishingly consistent gold standard for a style that is more hyped than ever, and Goose Island continues to hit it out of the park despite one significant speed bump of a year.  ---  I've since opened another bad 2015 bottle, and for the record: green olive brine.  ---  I can't help but note, as of 11/22/17, I got to be one of the first in Ohio to ever enjoy one of these on draft during Thanksgiving week, and got to do so as a side by side with this year's first ever Knob Creek Reserve, and there was no contest: this was markedly better. BCBS is unquestionably an expertly crafted barrel-aged stout. This is especially true when considering the fact that it is an originator of such an explosively popular sub-style, and still stands out amongst a younger class of competitors after all these years. This is one to be envied for decades to come, despite the current ownership, and even the QC issues.  ---  As of 2018, their insane consistency remains strong.  ---  My 2019 experience was notable in only that there was nothing new of note, so as Thanksgiving weekend 2020 comes around, I do find the need to make some new remarks here.  The consensus seems to be that this is a unique year, with dark fruit being the predominant flavor descriptor over all else, and I'm in agreement. Not so much in a bad way, but it's more exclusionary than collaborative than it has been before. There's also a Jack & Coke character, with some peppery Maker's Mark qualities.  Overall it seems as though it's been imparted with a bit of a younger spirit via lower quality barrels than past vintages, as if from a fresher liquor that allows for less barrel cohesion, which makes it seems a little less expertly produced than years past, for me.  ---  At the end of 2020, I did a side by side of July 2016 vintage Black Note with a 2013 Bourbon County.  I found the Bell's to have less carbonation than the Goose Island, which is a little odd with the BCBS being 3 years its senior. Additionally, the Bells was more chocolatey, smooth and easy to drink in that regard. It's very nutty with a neutral wood that does not increase any booze. There are additional notes of cigar and a hint of this strange, musky evergreen cologne that my old lady seems to have translated convincingly as honey, but just continues to strike me as some kind of aftershave or deodorant, no matter how faint it is.  Either way, the Black Note is a far more stout-forward beer, whereas the Bourbon County contained much more barrel booze, as well as far more actual bourbon character, bringing with that heat plentiful ribbons of vanilla and coconut. It's almost rum-like, and certainly less stout-forward, but the craziest thing of note to me is that I find absolutely no dark fruit at all, especially since more recent vintages have already started to exhibit raisin and prune characteristics. It's got a lighter body with a nice effervescence that's overall very pleasant and lifting for such a big, deep beer, making it very drinkable in its own way.  There's really no loser here, as both bring quite enjoyable experiences to the table years down the line, but for the record, I gave the edge to BCBS while the old lady stood behind BN.  ---  At the end of February 2021, I opened a 2014 vintage that had an amazing charred maple quality to it. As I found this quality paired with additional notes of Riesen and an underlying peppery barrel heat exhaling a delectable hint of decadent smoke, I couldn't find a single flaw and loved every drop of it.  ---  In 2021, while it's intensely dark fruit forward this year, it's not unenjoyably so. In fact it's quite pleasing where barrel char ribbons thru the malt expressing cocoa dusted date & syrupy molasses. Medium of body, it's frothier yet stinging on the finish. After time, tho, that heat does amplify an unusually acrid bitterness on the back end that BCBS doesn't normally exhibit.

Revisited with a 2019 vintage; poured from 0.5-liter bottle into a stemmed goblet. Appearance is straight-up motor oil, with a wisp of a tan head that quickly settled to a thin ring. Everything about this screams "Bourbon." Bourbon and barrel dominate the profile, with huge aromas and flavors of molasses and licorice. Not much in the way of char, but there is a ton of alcohol heat. This is about a full-bodied as you can get, with an almost syrupy mouthfeel and quite a bit of sweetness to boot. Molasses and licorice linger on the finish. If you're not a fan of bourbon, this one probably isn't for you.
2015 vintage enjoyed April 2016

Bottled 9/24/14. Served in a tulip glass.  Pours a jet black silky motor oil that leaves virtually no head. Aromas of cherries, alcohol, vanilla, wood, syrup, and dark chocolate. Taste is complex with a real thick chocolate upfront that transitions into a woody alcohol burn finish. Mouthfeel is heavy and chewy.  True to its name Bourbon County takes its cues from the barrel. You definitely get more of the bourbon than stout flavor. At 13.8% abv it packs a punch. A great brew to share with friends and family around the holidays. Perhaps a bit too much hype surrounding this series but this one is the more easily found beer in the Bourbon County line up so if you see it pick one up. That is if you can afford it.  Cheers!

2015 bottle (14.3 abv) poured into a snifter.  A: pitch black with very thin tan head  S: straight bourbon, raisin, oak  T: smokey malts, delicious bourbon  M: very thick and creamy. Pretty chewy  O: this was my first time trying and was blown away. I have never tasted such a thick and creamy stout. Picked up 2 bottles. I will save one for next year to compare to next year's batch.

Probably the most overrated beer I've ever had. Pour is heavy with no head. Taste like stale bourbon and stale beer mixed together and aged in a rotting wooden barrel. It leaves you with a disgusting aftertaste that stays in the throat forever.

Strong Bourbon, vanilla oak, raisins, semi sharp booze that is cut by sweetness. I do love this stout but the bourbon booziness does overshadow most of the flavor profile and I am left missing some of my favorite coffee and dark chocolate notes that are more present in the style. For those of you new to the style, try letting it warm so more of the complexity comes through. Great beer to share with my wife on Christmas Day (her gift to me!). Lives up to its hype but I would prefer more dark roasted malt to shine to balance out the sweet vanilla caramel of the bourbon.

Pours dark with very little head. First dip takes in the entire flavor with a beautifully aroma.  Just finished Christmas dinner with my folks and split a 750ml of brooklyn black ops with my father so I had a stout in my mind. Drove back to tampa from Sarasota and stopped at the copper top pub and noticed they have a shelf full of these... So glad I got to try.

This beer pours black with a medium sized head. The nose offers up a huge dose of booziness, followed by walnut, vanilla, and cinnamon. The flavor is fairly sweet, with strong vanilla, oak, baking spice, and bourbon flavors. The mouthfeel is rich and filling. Overall this is a very good beer for showcasing what bourbon barrel aging can do, but not as complex or nuanced as others I have had.

Enjoyed a 2015 bottle post Christmas feast with several craft beer newbies. I shared the story of the beer and they were amazed with the story of how this beer is made, and how hard it is to obtain. Of course they all thought it was amazing, this is a legend.
Exceptional

Taste of alcohol is noticeable, malty flavor, no head, hardly any carbonation. Potent caramel smell. Not enough carbonation for my liking, rather flat. Certainly lives up to its Bourbon aspect. I found this beer to be very similar in character to St. Bernardus Abt 12. Would I purchase this again? Likely not, only because I don't enjoy the overly sweet taste. I felt that I had to try it though from all the raves I had heard. For those who truly enjoy this flavor of beer, my review, I'm sure, will do no justice. I found the flavoring too sweet. I think I'd enjoy their coffee stout much more than this. I'm curious about the taste deviation against the Barleywine counterpart.
Has this in a 11oz goblet. Pub has this on tap. Not much of a head, good chocolate and roasted Smell. The bourbon is nice spicey bite at the end of my taste.

2015 vintage poured into Simon Pearce tulip  Oily, inky black appearance. No head, just thin traces of khaki.  Very boozy smell. Bourbon, more bourbon, vanilla, and raisin. I get some spiced rum as well.  Bourbon, cocoa, dark molasses. A bit of fruit, maybe prune. The ABV is well masked however.  This is a beer you can chew on. Viscous, lightly carbonated, the flavored really stick with you.  This is my first time with the legendary BCBS. The hype is extreme, but this is a world class representation of the style.

Phenomenal offering from Goose Island. Thanks to my brother for getting me 10 of these!!! Initially, the bourbon scent is strong but it gently tapers off to leave you with aromas of vanilla, caramel, some fruitiness, and, oh yeah, bourbon. They all come together to bring this 14.3% ABV masterpiece into a surprisingly easy to drink stout worthy of the hype. Now with all that being said, it is not my favorite imperial stout. My favorite stout, hands down...I've had one of these every year since 2014, so far 2018 vintage is (by far) the best. Sipping on 2020 right now just before Thanksgiving 2022. Excellent!!!!

I (like an idiot) did not believe the hype of this beer. I thought that somehow being owned by Anheuser-Busch Brewing company somehow took credit away. The beer is beautiful, a dissipating head and deep color looked appealing. The explosive sweetness cut by alcohol made me wish there was more. The abv made me happy I didn't.
Smells of bourbon, nice dark color, very little head, tastes of brown sugar and chocolate, the 14% abv is well hidden. Great taste, but certainly doesn't stand far above all BA stouts.

I lucked into finding a total of 16 bottles of this wonderful nectar. 14 regular and 2 of the barley wine. I have yet to try the barley wine but I found the regular to be much easier to drink than last years offering. I drank both side by side to weigh the differences. Even after a year the 2014 was almost too bourbony tasting and I like bourbon. I am going to age about ten of these and drink one a year for the next ten years to compare each new vintage. Enjoy if you can find any more! On another note, I don't know why bars sell this cold on tap, I understand they pretty much have to but this beer is so much better just below room temperature. The flavors are way better!

From a 16.9oz bottle (14.3% bottled 23OCT15) into a snifter, pours black, but with a deep ruby edge showing with light behind it. Very small mocha-colored head that never completely disappears. Smells like bourbon initially, then that's mixed with ripe dark fruits and toffee/caramel. Alcohol is pretty strong on the nose.  Taste has bourbon throughout, but is joined with the fruit/toffee flavors. Definitely boozy but not unpleasantly so. Sweetness is spot on. Feel is outstanding, with a smooth thickness that's nicely cut with a little carbonation.  Overall this is a masterful BA stout. The thing that impresses me is how all the flavors come together into something that, while I can pick out different elements like bourbon and fruit, still are almost more than the sum of their parts, adding up to something singular yet complex.

500 ml bottle poured into a stemmed glass. Doing this one in two shifts. Paired with long-grain brown rice, root vegetables and veggie sausage. Let's party.  Appearance: Black as night. Short tan head that reduces to bubbles and stays that way. Not much lacing.  Aroma: Bourbon, chocolate, rum cake, coffee, vanilla, smoke. Somewhat forbidding. Clearly a beer that means business.  Taste: Follows the nose pretty perfectly. Kind of reminds me of chocolate rum cake. Bourbon is very noticeable, and there's definitely booze heat, but it's a perfect combination of flavors. Vanilla's there, chocolate's there.  Mouthfeel: Velvet smooth with a burn on the finish. Perfect.  Overall: Damned near perfect stout. A triumph.

2018 bottle: L - Pitch, opaque black with a very thin dark tan head that dissipates almost immediately leaving behind no head and no lacing. S - Sweet, rich bourbon on the nose along with rich dark chocolate, caramel, toffee, dark fruits, and oak T - Follows the nose: sweet rich bourbon and dark chocolate up front followed by notes of caramel, vanilla, toffee, dark fruits, raisin, molasses, charred wood and slight alcohol warmth on the back end but it's not too noticeable and regardless, it's very drinkable and smooth for the percentage F - Full bodied with a light amount of carbonation - smooth, silky - somewhat chewy and viscous as it warms O - This is a fantastic stout - it's nothing flashy, but stays true to its roots and hits just about everything right. Incredibly complex but well integrated and balanced flavors, incredibly smooth for 15.2% - definitely up there in terms of best BBA stouts.  2022 - tons of vanilla, dark chocolate - almost fudge-like, and toffee up front and throughout, caramel and dried fruits - dates, raisins - sweet bourbon, some berry fruit, definitely some molasses, very slight hints of oak but not nearly as produced or charred as other years, roasted malt balances everything out. 2022 definitely feels like a safe year for this stout - it's incredibly executed and well done, but somewhat safe.

From the 500 ml bottle which cost fifteen bucks. Simply no foam at all. I poured into a couple different glasses. Mouthfeel is syrup. Aroma of, I swear, Manischewitz blackberry wine topped off with vodka.  Molasses is the predominate taste with a serious overdose of licorice. I don't taste the alleged Bourbon much. I keep thinking of Sugar Daddy suckers. The caramel taste just lingers. Seems like kind of a sugary alcoholic mess to me, and it doesn't get any better as it warms. I always look for Bourbon barrel flavored brews since my wife always likes to try them, and I think most of them are both tastier and more drinkable than this.

Ordered on draft at Union Pub in Washington DC. Marked as 14.2% in the menu.  Look: Dark with tan head.  Smell: Mostly bourbon and roasted malt.  Taste: Coffee, bourbon, vanilla, rum chocolate cake. Alcohol is very obvious but not too hot for me.  Feel: Very creamy, thick, almost chewy.  Overall: Fantastic. Lives up to the hype.

14.3% enjoyed from a bottle in a tulip/snifter at World of Beer in The Villages, Florida.  Half finger head settles to a ring. Dark tan. Body is dark brown. Little to no lacing.  Raisin. Bourbon. Vanilla. Caramel.  Raisin is strong. Caramel. Vanilla. Chocolate. Char. Bourbon. Smoke.  For some reason doesn't sit as well as the coffee. Smooth for abv. Definitely warms you up.  Raisin. A lot of raisin. Came from Ohio to get warm in Florida.

Wow! This is a good beer. I am not a bourbon drinker, but these bourbon barrel beers are really starting to grow on me. Others talk of licorice but I don't taste it, and that is good because I don't like licorice. Sweet finish. Not too much alcohol for a high gravity beer. You got to try this one, if you can find it.

This is my first experience with this legendary brew. Time to see what all the hype is about. Special thanks to Jason for hooking me up with a couple bottles.  Poured from a 16.9oz. bottle. (Bottled on 10-15-2015)  A: Pours almost completely opaque black with about an inch of deep chestnut brown colored head. Retains for about a minute before receding. Leaves very little lacing. The pitch of the beer is a perfect example of a stout but I am slightly disappointed with the head/retention.  S: Deep and complex aromas of dark roasted malts, vanilla, bourbon and charred oak like smokiness bombard you nostrils initially. Then you find notes of caramel, dark chocolate, molasses, black licorice, leather, and faint tobacco. As it warms the aromas really pop and as you dig deeper you'll also find notes of marshmallow, toffee, dark fruits, coconut, faint maple, and some faint earthy hops. Absolutely fantastic nose on this brew. I could smell this for days.  T: Wow... The first sip in incredibly inviting, it follows the nose well as you immediately get a nice bourbon booziness accoPoured from a 16.9oz. bottle. (Bottled on 10-15-2015)  A: Pours almost completely opaque black with about an inch of deep chestnut brown colored head. Retains for about a minute before receding.  S: Deep and complex aromas of dark roasted malts, vanilla, bourbon and charred oak like smokiness bombard you nostrils initially. Then you find notes of caramel, dark chocolate, molasses, cinnamon, black licorice, leather, and faint tobacco. As it warms the aromas really pop and as you dig deeper you'll also find notes of marshmallow, toffee, dark fruits, coconut, faint maple, and some faint earthy hops. Absolutely fantastic nose on this brew. I could smell this for days.  T: Wow, the very first sip of this brew is incredibly inviting, it follows the nose well with big flavors of dark roasted malts, vanilla, a perfect level of bourbon booziness, a nice oak smokiness, dark chocolate, and molasses. The you find caramel, tobacco, dark fruits, black licorice, coconut, and toffee, Much like the nose as it warms much more seems to come alive as you get faint flavors of marshmallow, coffee, maple, a slight hint of grassy and earth like hops, berries, figs, and brown sugar. This is easily one of the best beers to ever grace my tongue.  M: Full bodied, lightly carbonated, slick and oily texture with an incredibly smooth feel. Has a nice warming effect and overall pleasant booziness. Definitely a sipper that should be enjoyed slowly.  O: I must admit I love this beer. I really did not expect it to be so good. I can understand all the hype now and can see why it has become so hard to get a hold of. We didn't even get any in the St. Cloud MN area, if it wasn't for Jason I would have missed out yet again. This is a truly world class example of it's style. As a man who's favorite brews tend to be BA Stouts and Barleywines I can say this has rightfully earned it's place in my top brews hierarchy. Even as I have evolved my palate and really become a lot stricter in what I think of brews, this one really stands out to me as wow that wasn't a beer that was an experience. To sum it all up everyone should seek this one out, find someone to enjoy it with (I shared mine with my Bro) and experience the experience that it has to offer.

(Review for the 2015 bottle) First time ever having the BCBS! Although I'm a tad bit disappointed with the initial tasting... I'm definitely looking forward to tasting the brew again, after it ages for a bit.  -Looks like black death; so spot on for a stout. Although absolutely no head at all,,, :( I like head. -Smells like a 14% should smell: You can definitely pick up the booze (in this case a nice bourbon smell), but the molasses/black licorice does a nice job mellowing the alcohol out. -Tastes almost like it smells: Strong bourbon notes, and a (overwhelmingly) strong molasses finish. Picking up slight vanilla, black licorice, (maybe) some carmel.  Solid beer, although a bit too hot for me...(also I find the molasses to be potent as hell)). Welp can't wait to taste after aging, just hope the other flavors decide to show up after having some rest time. Will update after said hibernation!

I acquired enough of this that I decided to open one now. Poured into a small snifter. A - Pours black with very little head. S - Aroma is molasses, black licorice and booze which I find to be wonderful. T - The flavor is similar to the nose. Definitely molasses and black licorice but also a little chocolate. The booze is just perfect. M - Thick mouth feel, very little carbonation. O - I'm a big believer in letting this beer sit for a year. All of the 2014 bottles I've opened have been awesome. This is a great beer and I can't wait to taste it once it gets a little shelf time on it. That being said, I've had 3 bottles now and I'm convinced the 2015 version is perfect.

Bottled 10/15/2014. 13.8% Pours a deep chestnut brown color, not a completely opaque beer but looks thick and oily nonetheless, with a minimal toasted khaki head that recedes to nothing. The aroma hits you as soon as you hear the hiss, decadent fudge, bourbon, toasted coconut, burnt caramel, oak, vanilla, sweet tobacco, dark fruits, heavy roast, and ash. The body is full but a little thinner than the previous versions (haven't found the '15 yet), not too carbonated, sticky and mouth-coating but nicely balanced between the sweetness, bitter roast, and alcohol heat. There's a savoriness to this beer. Flavor has everything you want in a big barrel-aged stout but I still think this one isn't on par with the other vintages. Dark roasted espresso, black malt, molasses, raisins, bittersweet chocolate, leather, coconut, big barrel character, brown sugar, and licorice candy. I wonder how my 2012 and '13's are doing? Also makes me realize that, despite the price increase this year, it's probably worth grabbing a 2015 vintage, if they're still around...

First time tasting this beer, had on draft. So much bourdon smell and amazing taste. Was blown away and lucky to be able to have it, even though it was $8 for an 8oz glass. Well worth the price no matter what it is. Amazing beer so lucky to finally have it. Cheers!

Serving Type: Bottle (dated 10.15.15) Consumed: 12.12.15  A: 4.5 Pours pitch black and looks very thick coming out of the bottle. The tan head is rather small, even after an aggressive pour, and lasts less than a minute.  S: 4.75 Smells of sweet bourbon and vanilla with moderate roasted malt presence. The aromas really open up as the beer warms to 60 or 65 degrees; more vanilla, molasses, licorice, marshmallow, and coconut start to come through.  T: 4.75 Classic bourbon barrel aged stout – the prototype really. Nearly perfect. Sweetness kicks things off with vanilla, marshmallow, bourbon, caramel, and coconut. Gradually, the roasted malt takes over, first brining bittersweet chocolate and licorice, then moderate levels of coffee. The finish is slightly bitter, blending nicely with a last bit of sweetness and dark berries.  M: 4.75 Thick and rich. Pretty low level of carbonation – great for the style.  O: 4.75 Not sure why it took so long to review this beer. I guess I thought I’d rate if fresh, and wow is the 2015 is great fresh (as were other vintages). Ages gracefully, becoming more fudgy and rich.

A: Pitch black. Thin mocha head.  S: Bourbon, chocolate shop, rough hewn wood, worked leather, licorice, molasses.  M: Full bodied, slight chew. Radiant heat. Medium carb, some good astringency.  T: Caramel, dark chocolate laceing. Oak chips. Strong elements of smoky leather, vanilla almond anise biscotti. Finishes chocolate malt ball and espresso.

Pours an inky, pitch black with minimal effervescence and scant light brown head. Smells strongly of vanilla, oak, cocoa, leather and smoke. Tastes sweet malts forward, vanilla, cocoa, caramel, bourbon like with its woody and leather notes, well balanced by the dry notes of the bourbon. Thick body with fair amount of astringency – not syrupy and leaves a pleasant, sweet malty finish with the barest hint of a bourbon twang. Increases in complexity as it warms. . . Overall, the best bourbon barrel aged stout I’ve ever had. Goose Island stays true to the recipes for which it is famous – another solid beer from Goose Island.

2015 version  L - Pitch black, oil, not much head or lacing, but some tan bubbles swirl around on the top  S - Bourbon, chocolate, roasted malts, licorice, and booze  T - dark chocolate, lots of it. Warming and slightly boozy. So damn smooth. A perfect bourbon stout. It gets better as it warms  F - medium body, and oily slick.  O - I get the hype. It's fantastic. Glad I got a few more to age.

After waiting in line at my local Bevmo to buy a case. it turns out that the Safeway right next door got more bottles. So at a club price of 8.09 a bottle two cases came home with me.  Look: not as black as you would think. Imagine brown ink. Has a small head that dissipates quickly.  Smell: bourbon, spice (maybe the fusels showing up), oak, toasted oak, caramel, and lots of chocolate.  Taste: Being an avid bourbon drinker, this was everything I wanted in a bourbon beer. It has all the pleasantries of bourbon but without the heat. There is some heat from the alcohol, but, boy is this a sweet bomb. If it wasn't 10 bucks a bottle I would make an ice cream float out of it.  Feel: Amazingly they are able to capture some of the same oiliness that my favorite bourbons have. There is thicker viscosity to this beer. Not chewy, but thick.  Overall: Glad I got two cases, this is in my top three beers. The smell was the only weak point for me.

2015.  Look: pavement, charcoal, black but with a gray hint  Smell: lots of licorice, pine, some alcohol  Taste: explosion of flavors, licorice calms down a lot, some earthy wood flavors, not much alcohol but an explosion right on the swallow, definite smokiness  Feel: very thick, heavy on the tongue, didn't expect that  Overall: blew my mind in a lot of ways. puts all my other stout/porter experiences into a different view now.

L - This is a thick liquid of high viscosity that coats the glass well with thin lacing. The lace looks like a burnt brown sugar flake sitting on top. Quickly disappears.  S - Boozy and caramel with hints of chocolate, cocoa, dark fruits and oh yeah....bourbon.  T - Caramel & boozy fudge pop. can really taste the booze as it warms up. This would be a great topping on vanilla flan or even ice cream. Vanilla bean ice cream.  F - Low carbonation with some very little heat from the booze. Thick and sticky.  O - Very nice!! I'm going to age one however. I think it needs a bit more time so the booze can mellow out.

Posting my first review with a big dog. 2015 in a Tulip glass.  This is my first experience with Bourbon County Stout. L - Pitch Black with good consistency. Relatively small khaki brown head with a little lacing S - Sweet and Smoky smell with good bourbon notes and vanilla. T - I tasted caramel, raisins, dark chocolate, and cherry poprocks. F - Not too thick, not too thin. Good consistency. O - An excellent barrel aged stout but as a first tier, I found it a little sweet. And I like sweet beers. Still looking forward to the next bottle. Cheers
you can definitely taste the vanilla caramel and a hint of chocolate. Alcohol taste is somewhat overwhelming, though.

Had it on draft at the Hopleaf. Pours super black but with pretty minimal head. Scent is very powerful: vanilla is what stood out the most but also chocolate, coffee, and rich dark fruit. Taste is almost identical, though the bourbon and booze factor in. My one very minor criticism is that I taste the booze a bit too much. Texture is viscous, though a bit thinner than others in the style. Overall, a great beer but does not quite live up to the hype or the price.

Look - Completely jet black, viscous, motor oil, no head to speak of really, coats the glass as you swirl it around. Smell - WOW!! Couldn't remove my nose from the glass. Vanilla, caramel, bourbon, oakiness, chocolate. Absolutely breath taking. Taste - Bourbon, tons of vanilla, tons of caramel, tons of milk chocolate, toasted coconut, toffee Feel - GLORIOUS! Rich, decadent, thick, oily, mouth coating  Overall - Cant imagine a BA stout tasting better than this. This beer is perfect in every way.

Aggressive pour resulted on a small tan head that dissipated quickly and left no lacing. Smells of oak, vanilla, sweet bourbon and a bit or roastiness. Tastes of sweet dark fruits, bourbon, vanilla, chocolate and the right touch of roast and bitterness to balance it out. Very well done! Has a silky smooth medium-full mouth feel that leave a lingering bourbon sweetness but surprisingly isn't cloying. Overall...and excellent beer!

Type: 500ml (16.9-oz.) glass Glass: AleSmith Barrel-Aged Reserve snifter glass From: Whole Foods in Manhattan Beach, Calif. Price: $10.99 Purchased: Nov. 27, 2015 Consumed: Dec. 6, 2015 Misc.: Bottled on Sept. 22, 2015  Poured an almost pitch black color with 1-to-2 fingers of dark khaki tan, fizzy head. Average lacing on the sides of the glass. Average retention. (Sight - 4.00)  First smell was crayon, immediately followed by chocolate, vanilla, boozy bourbon, lightly toasted coconut, earthy figs, faint tobacco, caramel, toffee, molasses and burnt plastic. (Smell - 4.25)  First thought on the taste was holy shit. Just awesome. Probably even better than I thought it would be. Got milk chocolate, sugary molasses, dark sticky caramel, vanilla, toasted coconut, boozy warm bourbon, light woody notes, cocoa powder, light figs, dates, faint tobacco and toffee. (Taste - 4.75)  Full body. Sticky texture. Average carbonation. Long, smooth finish. (Feel - 5.00)  This was just an awesome beer. As good as advertised and I’m glad I finally got to try it. Can’t wait to try some variants. (Overall - 4.75)  4.61 | 100 | A+
2015 edition bought by asking if the store had any. Loads of bourbon on taste and nose, a bit of oak and hint of vanilla. A hot shock of alcohol followed by a warming sweetness. Perfect.

2015 release. 14.2% abv. 16.9oz bottle into a 24oz globe  This is my first experience with BCBS and I wanted to be completely unbiased. Enjoyed this beverage on my 34th birthday, sitting in bed, after a 14 hour day of work  L: Dark Black with a tiny caramel head-quickly faded, possibly the only thing that wasn't overly impressive about this beer~4.25  S: Very average BA stout smell while it was cold (refrigerated temp). As it warmed, tons and tons of aroma coming out. Vanilla, Coffee, Chocolate, bourbon, I was most surprised by a cinnamon scent. ~5  T: Followed the nose pretty closely, minus the cinnamon. lots of sweetness, as expected and the bourbon was perfect, not overwhelming at all. The chocolate and vanilla were both prevalent. I also picked up some raisin as the beer warmed. The very last sip was above room temp due to my hand warmth and I could really taste the malted barley and cereal flavors. Everything was in perfect balance. ~5  F: I found it to be very smooth in the mouth. It was far from thin but moved easily through the mouth and down the throat. Medium to full body. I think it worked well though, nothing about the beer was harsh. ~4.5  O: This may be up there with the best beer I've ever had. I didn't want to jump on the band wagon blindly, but BCBS completely nailed it. It wasn't just having a beer, it was truly an experience. I couldn't keep my nose out of the glass, and I let each sip linger in my mouth, over the course of an hour and a half. I've read reviews claiming too much heat and overly sweet, but I didn't find anything out of balance. Excellent ~5

I had two different bottles. One bottled October 13, 2015 with an Abv of 14.2 that was released in MA and the other was bottled November 4, 2015 that I received in Iowa. The one from MA was much smoother. The one in Iowa was very hot and could use more time on it. I'm not sure if this is an example of different types of barrels used or not. Very much enjoyed the MA release better. As for the beer at hand, there are very few bourbon aged beers that fall into this status.
This is def a sipping beer!

2015 bottle poured into teku.  Look: Pitch black with dark brown head which dissipates quickly. Smell: Oaky vanilla, roastiness. Taste: Like the aroma, tons of vanilla and oak. Nice bourbon sweetness. Also chocolate and caramel undertones. Feel: Silky smooth with a nice level of carbonation. Alcohol very well masked. Dangerous!  Overall: Wow! This stuff is great. Can definitely understand why everybody loves this beer.Even without adjuncts this beer is awesome. Really tasty and nuanced. Its nice sipping this on a cold night and can appreciate the format. Popped open a bottle and I was content the rest of the night. Glad I picked up more and might hunt a couple more down now that I've tasted it.

I had to search high and low to get this in nm. I was late to the game. Even though I was a new comer to the whiskey barrel beer I was very pleased with this beer. Great right out of the bottle. Even more excited to age a bottle and try later down the road. For immediate whiskey barrel satisfaction I'll stick to bwb but look forward to these after some aging.

2015 on draft thanks to the good folks at Brass Tap Ybor City! Pours thick and viscous. Dark, dark brown with a tiny dark tan head that quickly dissipates. Very noticeable meniscus from alcohol. Aroma of bourbon and dark fruit, and alcohol. Taste follows aroma with lots of black licorice.  Great example of bourbon barrel stouts.

Had this poured on tap today and it packs a punch. Smoky char....almost campfire mixed with deep Cocoa nibs and roasted nuttiness to the smell and flavor. I think cellaring would improve and further blend the flavors into a masterpiece

Motor oil dark pour with a little brown head that dissipates quickly. The smell is massive bourbon, wood, caramel, toffee, chocolate. Taste is the same. Extremely complex with layers of bourbon, vanilla, dark roasted malts, chocolate, coffee. Thick, full mouthfeel with medium-low carbonation. This is just a world class beer.

WOW! I was ready to be disappointed with all the hype around this beer, but I was impressed. The 2015 BCBS has got to be one of the best beers I've tasted.  The look : Dark ruddy brown almost black - I held my glass up to the light to see if I could get any glimmer or a spot of shine - not a noticeable spot. It was poured at around 70deg and as it sat in the glass and what little carbonation dissipated the legs that developed were mesmerizing.  The smell : fantastic, deep chocolate, dark coffee, Molasses, dark fruit.  The taste : Chocolate, Coffee first, then other flavors start to emerge... notes of figs, dark molasses, oak, raison. Complex and satisfying sipped for over an hour.  The Feel : thick on the tongue and filled the mouth, no alcohol burn at all, but warmed the chest.  Overall : I felt like I should have been sitting in a hunting lodge by a fire after a long day riding and enjoying a good cigar, not sitting in my office. This is truly an elite beverage. I am glad we managed to get three bottles, the only problem is I want to drink them and share them with friends and I want to see what this heaven in a bottle is like when it is aged.

2015 vintage, 14.3% in a bourbon snifter drank out of a bottle 12/4/2015  L - thick, viscous, creamy. Minimal lacing with a minimal tan head  S - bourbon and chocolate with a little burnt toast and oak. It's a powerful boozy smell  T - bourbon is strong along with a nice sweet dark chocolate layer. This is pretty consistent throughout. As it warms, these layers continue among some new players to the game....oak, char, and very nice vanilla notes. The vanilla is surprisingly strong. A little dark fruit and some caramel on the very back end. Bourbon and dark chocolate are among every layer.  F - viscosity galore! This is a nice thick beer that is dangerously drinkable. No booze or heat after a little boozy smell.  Overall - This is an amazing beer. The GI Bourbon County Brand Stout beers are elite. If this beer had no variants and was released with 90% less bottles, I am certain this would be among the top 3 BA beers in the world. This will age well, but due to no heat or booze, this is a fantastic fresh barrel aged beer. Thanks again Goose!
An experience to drink. Exceptional.

I am a newbie at the bourbon barrel aged stouts having only had KBS prior to tonight. BCBS was an amazing experience though. Not much head to speak of but blacker than the blackest cliche. Smell was strong bourbon with faint vanilla. Very smooth taste though, and this from a non-bourbon guy. I mean, it's there in force don't get me wrong but it's so smooth and delicious. Nice sweetness. 16.9 oz was a perfect serving size. This opened a door for me that I don't see closing.

Pours black cream color head dissipates quickly. Smell bourbon vanilla and oak notes. Taste is WOW the bourbon taste is not overwhelming but blends well with the vanilla and slight coffee taste. Medium bodied you can taste the bourbon after you take a sip no strong after taste. Overall this is an amazing beer.

Vertical tasting, 2013, 3014, 2015. First two beers are much bigger and better than 2015. Opaque, expresso-like head. Full body, silky texture, intense flavors, high alcohol heat, lingering palate. Sweet, moderate bitterness. Tar, roses, alcohol and roasted flavors. Excellent, couldn't imagine any better.

Poured fairly warm, cellar temp.  Dark, almost black but not quite. Lots of coffee and a good deal of sweet malt notes. Lots of vanilla and coffee and sweetness. Very mild heat, super smooth. Creamy mouth feel. Full bodied and with no carbonation.

Fantastic! This is as good as it gets. Being that I can't have Westy 12 anymore, and I cannot get Speedway Stout in Florida, this rates with Rochefort 10 as the best beer I can buy local (although it's not easy to get it, it goes so fast!). I had the 2013,14, and 15 on tap at #3 Craft Brews in Cape Coral, and they were all great. The 2013 was the smoothest, but they were all fantastic. I had the bottled version last year, and it was equally sublime. Beer at it's best!
Smooth, strong. If you like imperial stouts you will love this

2015 Vintage Look- Dark as midnight. No light is getting through this. Poured into 12oz snifter. A finger of head that dissipates quickly.  Smell- Bourbon, vanilla, toasted coconut, fig, leather and tobacco on the nose.  Taste- Fantastic. More of the bourbon, vanilla and coconut here. Oak, chocolate and dark stone fruits round it out. The alcohol is not a major player here. This beer is remarkably balanced fresh.  Feel- Spot on, great mouth feel. Thick and viscous, as you would expect.  Overall- This is as good of a beer as I've had in awhile (gave me the wow factor I had w/ santas lil helper bourbon barrel aged). Usually I find most bourbon county beers to be a bit of a train wreck right out of the gate, but this one is exceptional. Should and can be consumed now.

Disclaimer: first bourbon barrel aged stout  55° Jet black pour with a nice 2 1/2 finger head that left quickly. 16 Oz snifter. WOW! Bourbon aroma hits hard. Some smoke, char and dark chocolate. I suck at picking up vanilla notes. Sip.............where in the f $♤☆ has this been all my life!!!!! Intense bourbon barrel (I ♡ bourbon ) hits my mouth and pleasure centers of my brain. Finished with toffe, dark chocolate and cocoa with probably the best mouthfeel ever. Heavy but not too heavy. Is it boozy? Duh! Boozy in the best possible way. 14.3% ABV but amazing well balanced. I know I tend to rate high but this will be getting some 5s  New #1 fave beer ever

Black with a light brown head that dissipates quickly. Aroma of bourbon, molasses, vanilla, smoke, dark fruits, toasted coconut. Taste of bourbon, oak, vanilla, cocoa, roasted barley, coffee, dark fruits. Clean dry finish. Mouthfeel is oily and slick. All flavors combine wonderfully. Not hot at all. Worth the hype and defends itself as the original bourbon barrel aged stout.

It's so hard not to get caught up in the hype.  2015 BCBS is fantastic. Pours dark as night with a nice dark brown head. Nose of bourbon, oak, vanilla, caramel. Tastes like bourbon, charred oak, dark fruits, chocolate, malt, and deliciousness. Feel is spot on for the style, not thin by any stretch of the imagination, yet you don't need a fork and a knife to get through it.  People like to bash Bourbon County because of Goose Island's affiliation with InBev...but don't forget these guys were the first do to do this, they know exactly what they're doing. And without them, BA Stouts might not exist.

This is my 1st year having BCBS. I've enjoyed several bottles now and had it on tap a couple of different times. I enjoy everything about this beer, and can completely understand all the fuss it creates. It's very thick and viscous in the glass, and you can see the legs the alcohol creates. From the tap there is more of a noticeable head as you would expect. The aroma on this beer is amazing. Right up front there is a ton of bourbon and alcohol followed by all the notes a stout should hit. The taste matches the smell. It is a little hotter from the bottle than from the tap. I have several bottles aging at home, and I would expect the booziness to mellow with age. Overall, if you can get this beer do so. If you haven't had any, go do so immediately.

This year is my first trip to Bourbon County. I got 2 bottles of this one plus a Rare, Regal Rye, and Barleywine after about 7 hours of waiting in line...not too shabby. I also got a nice BCBS 2015 Spielgau tulip snifter for free at the event, which of course I am drinking out of for this review.  First things first, the hype is real! Okay, maybe not wake up at absurd hours and freeze your petunia off on a holiday weekend real, but this is quite possibly one of the thickest, mightiest, most intense and all-encompassing stouts I have ever had, on par with Founders KBS and Avery Uncle Jacob's. What I wouldn't give to someday do a side-by-side and see who the real winner is...  It pours an opaque black hole with a thick head about a shade darker than my khakis. Immediately the smell pours forth, and there isn't a whole lot that I'm not getting here. On first sniff, there's the obligatory rich chocolate, bourbon, and oak. Smelling more deeply gets molasses, figs, dates, barbecue smoke, and a lot of roasted barley, and a gallon of booze. A hint of vanilla, but not much despite it being written right there on the label.  Sidenote, my cat did NOT like the smell, and he usually tries to steal all my food.  Normally I'd notice flavor before mouth feel, but the first thing I noticed when I was sipping this was that it feels like you're sipping oil. It's so thick, slippery, and sticky that it just sits on your tongue and lips and never goes away. Possibly the thickest, oiliest beer I've ever encountered.  But look out folks, because Bourbon County is Flavor Country! If you've ever tasted a barrel-aged stout, this is similar but a million times more so. (If you haven't, try a few before trying BCBS or you will spoil yourself forever of them.) A ton of alcohol burn makes it tough to put down more than a small sip at a time. Seriously, trying to get a big gulp would probably just trigger your gag reflex, that's how thick and boozy it is. But tons of bourbon flavor, but still tastes like a stout, chocolate, caramel, toasted malts, a hint of salty soy sauce...  Overall, this is one of the most stout stouts I've ever had. I totally get it. Is any beer worth disrupting your life for? Who knows? I had a ton of fun getting mine, but not sure if I'd do it again, especially these days where equal or almost equally good options are starting to appear and are less exclusive. But don't let the hype detract from the fact that this is truly and world-class imperial stout that deserves the highest honors.

Pours a dark cola brown that looks pitch black in the glass. An aggressive pour yields a finger of mocha brown head that quickly fades away into a thin ring that leaves splotchy along the glass. The nose is a mostly sweet blast of bourbon and vanilla, butterscotch, and caramel, with faint bitter cocoa, dates, and raisins. The flavors just melt in your mouth. Bourbon candy. Sweet yet balanced, creamy and smooth. The flavor of bourbon without the heat. Butterscotch, caramel, and brown sugar. Tons of vanilla. Plenty of dark chocolate, toast, and coffee behind the butterscotch-bourbon-vanilla sweetness. A smattering of dark fruits like dates, prunes, and raisins to compliment it. The mouthfeel is not thick or sludgy but is very oily, slick, and creamy. Drinks insanely easy for this high of abv.  I'm overjoyed that I was finally able to snag this. It lives up to the hype.

Pours jet black. Gives a half inch of coffee colored head that slowly thins. The nose is barrel, smoke, and toffee. Barrel and booze is the first impression then it mellowed into some kind of awesomeness. Light coco powder flavor dominated the finish. Very good job. This is an awesome barrel stout.

250th beer review!  2015 edition. 500 mL bottle into a Duvel glass. Pours a medium-dark brown and settles pitch black in the glass. About 1/2 a finger of dark tan head initially - this quickly fizzed down to a thin skirt that hung around the edges. HUGE aroma on this beer. I could smell it as I was pouring. Strong notes of bourbon, chocolate, burnt wood, molasses, caramel, vanilla, and maple syrup. Not a strong roasty malt smell, suprisingly. Awesome balanced aroma, and thankfully not overly boozy. The taste follows right along, not missing a beat. Delicious, sweet carmelized bourbon, oakey bitter coffee and chocolate, sweet vanilla, sticky molasses...wow. Notes of vanilla and caramel become more pronounced on the aftertaste. Great feel on this, too. Nice and dense but not to the point of being overly chewy. Incredibly smooth for 13.8%. While it is a tad hot, I'd say 8 months in the cellar would even this thing out to perfection. Incredibly well balanced and crafted.

I have always been just marginally interested in Goose Island beers. Their 312 and Honkers Ale are usually pretty safe choices when found on tap but not necessarily what I would call the top in their respective catagories.  Having said that the barrel aged Bourbon County Stout really impressed me. The flavor is complex enough that several sips are needed to really get the flavor profile.  My wife is not nearly as adventurous as I am in beers. She typically universally does not like the stout varieties. She tried this one and while it's not her new favorite beer she did try more than one taste and was impressed by the complexity of the flavors.  I plan to get three more of these as soon as I can. Two will be opened and shared on a beach in Florida preferably with a nice robust cigar. The other I will try to cellar for a while but I make no guarantees.

A - 4.5 - pitch black beer with mocha head that dissipates quickly, not much lacing, understandable for 14.3% abv S - 5 - huge smooth bourbon/vanilla/umami/creaminess all at once, dark malts in the background, molasses, hint of dark fruits, milk chocolate T - 5 - bourbon, vanilla, coconut, oak, molasses, butterscotch, umami, cream, milk chocolate, dark fruits (sweet red cherries and figs), dark malts are there but smoothed out, this is not a roasty beer nor is there bitterness from the dark malts M - 5 - thick.
