Creamy and milky, with more individual tastes than I can figure out from a single taste. Sweet and grainy bourbon, but so much more subdued than in a lesser barrel-aged beer; creamy chocolate; vanilla bean and oak; barely noticeable hop bite.  The bourbon comes in on the initial flavor, and comes in again on the back end, wonderfully book-ending perfectly smooth chocolate malts.  Thickest, fullest mouthfeel I think I've ever had. Absolutely chewy. Very warm; there's no avoiding the fact that this beer clocks in at 14.2%, but it's done phenomenally well. Tiny sting from carbonation; it lends a very necessary balance to what is otherwise a silkily smooth and creamy dessert.  I honestly did not expect to be this impressed, because I don't like bourbon. Its influence is undeniable, but instead of overpowering the stout flavors, it really does complement them perfectly.  This is the only beer to enjoy over an evening, and to be enjoyed slowly and lovingly. I can't believe how well-made it is; it may not be my favorite stout right now, but it is the best.

This was a 12oz 2013 bottle that I drank just 2 days after its release on Black Friday. I drank it from a snifter at around 56°F within one hour. ABV is 14.9%  A - After popping the cap and hearing that slight fizz, a thin body with deep black color poured out. They say "motor-oil" thick, but this beer has a motor-oil color. Super dark and not a fraction of light shines through it. Zero head even after a vigorous pour, and what almost looked like a forming head, quickly dissipated. A thin line of brown bubbles lines the glass around where the beer's surface sits.  S - As soon as you crack this bad boy, subtle sweet bourbon notes float around you. Even at a distance of 2 feet I still get wafts of that sugary booze. The scent is intensely sweet (in case you haven't picked up on that yet) with other notes of burnt malts, nutty chocolate, coffee, and of course bourbon.  T - Tasty cocoa nibs melted over a coffee-and-bourbon-infused, roasted almond with a sugary vanilla glaze would accurately describe the taste. Not sure if anyone has ever made such a thing, but this is it in liquid form... and it's damn delicious!  M - For a beer that's packing nearly 15% ABV, the way GI disguises the alcohol burn is beyond me. Very impressive. There's still a small amount of heat after a swallow, but none like any other >15% beer I've had. Moving onto carbonation... there isn't much, but that's expected from an imperial stout like this.  O - What a wonderful beer. I truly think that BCBS is the definition of bourbon barrel aged stouts. Not too sweet, hot, or thick. Goose Island prints on its label that it can age over 5 years in the bottle. I don't doubt that, and I'm excited to see how my other 7 bottles will develop over time. If you're on edge about trying one, I suggest you buy/trade for one now. Cheers!

On the nose get exactly what the name says straight bourbon oaky notes with the smell of dark roasted malt. The stars of this beer for me are the taste and appearance. The beer is pitch black in appearance exactly what i expect to see in an stout only disappointment is there was no real head to speak of, but at 14.9% what do you really expect. Now on to the taste 1st on the tongue you get the taste of oak followed by notes of maple, dark chocolate and roasted coffee. At 14.9% you really don't taste the alcohol the only thing you really get is a slight warming in the back of the throat to give you some warning of the alcohol content of this beer. Overall really complex beer so complex I really dont think I can put it in words, you defiantly have to try this beer for your self, well worth the hype.

12oz bottle poured into snifter  A - Nearly pitch black. A very slight mocha head when poured rather aggressively, this dissipates rather quickly.  S - Dark fruits, toffee, vanilla, bourbon. Faint chocolate smell and definitely a hit of booze.  T - Very smooth taste for such a high ABV. Vanilla, caramel, and chocolate I'm getting upfront. Followed by a dark roasty taste and dark fruits. Getting some boozy tons from the bourbon but definitely not overpowering. Still, definitely a sipper, thats for certain.  M - Very smooth. Full bodied with minimal carbonation.  O - What's there to say that hasn't been said by a thousand others?! This is the first I've been lucky enough to acquire a four pack and I see why it's so highly sought after. The bourbon flavor is absolutely amazing, it's perfect. Can't wait to age the others in my pack and enjoy at a later date

Love, love, love this beer! I have tried a ton of bourbon barrel ales, stouts, etc. but this by far has been the best I have had! Great dark, black color and not an overwhelming, but powerful bourbon aroma. Not a thick head but a dark brown tint. Taste was just like having a Makers Mark on the rocks! Sweet taste initially, followed by the classic stout flavor. This was a great beer and the 14% ABV is for real! I'm sitting here sipping on this in a chilled pint and I am feeling it!  Cheers everyone!

shame on me for even rating this beer. I am a beer freak but ABV above 9 is just too sweet for my taste.  This beer was so hyped that I just had to have it but I should known better than to go for these high ABVs.  you would think I would learn my lesson but no.  this is a really good beer for those who like the sweetness. other who have rated it have commented about the high bourbon flavor but I just didn't taste it

Previous review of 2008 Reserve on 3/07/2011: (4.66)  Not following regular format here.  This is a very near perfect beer. Age has done wonders for this beer. Tons on vanilla, bourbon, dark fruits, hints of chocolate and cake batter mellowed and blended perfectly together.  What can I say that already hasn't been said? When it comes to complexity in any beer I've ever had, I don't think there's ever been more.  The only downfall I can find is that it's a little sugary towards the end but at 13% it's expected. This is the only reason why this doesn't get 5's across the board excluding drinkability. Not sure any variation of BCS deserves a 5 in drinkability. Sipper for sure.  I'm SO happy after having this one that the RARE is the same year. I won't touch that one and only RARE I'm cellaring for at least another year.  SUBLIME!!!  2013 Re-Review:  Again, not following regular format here.  This displays everything flawlessly about what Bourbon Barrels lend to Beer. Obviously Stouts in general, but this for me is the perfect Bourbon barrel Aged beer.  Fudge cake pastry Chocolate soaked in Bourbon with some mild dark fruits and heat in the finish. Vanilla Oak and sticky, yet smooth. That sticky Barrel just lingers on the palate for days! Keep smacking my lips minutes after each sip, and Loving it.  Mouthfeel thick and sticky, yet Pure Satin Velvet and smooth.  This beer is fresh. Bottled in November 2013 and I'm finding this hard that much age will improved upon this specimen. When I had a 2008 bottle back in 2011, it was basically the same beer I'm tasting now from memory, only more sweet and sugary. If that is what age will do to this, I say drink this fresh! I can find no flaws. The epitome for the style IMHO.  The only other perfect 5 Beer I've given besides PtE after 4 & 1/2 years on this site.  ISO the base beer! Any takers?

A- pitch black ...smooth and silky. This thing crackled like rice crispys when aggressively poured. S- smokey , candied sugars , dark fruits , vanilla, bourbon , possibly some coffee , caramel , licorice .. really nice. T- the booze flavors in this is not really my thing but its well made. I can taste a lot of bourbon ,that caramel vanilla-ish flavor bourbon gives, slight coconut and coffee. M- fairly easy to drink and very silky on the tongue. O- I am glad it tried this awesome unique stout ,but I prefer others more.   Purchased at total wine in Naples , Fl for 17.99 a sixer.

Poured into a stemmed tulip from the 12 oz. bottle.  a: Dark Black with just a little brown around the edges. Small bubbles in light mocha colored head, no lacing and little head retention.  s: Not as alcohol/ bourbon forward as expected, very complex with toffee, smoke, oak and vanilla.  t: Much more Bourbon forward, very similar to the smell except some added booziness; toffee, smoke, oak and vanilla.  m: Smooth but thick, not super creamy though. Low carbonation but very full bodied.  o: Amazing, a world class beer that definitely still stands up to it's rating. If you really want to pick nits, it doesn't have great head retention and is a little light on carbonation. Awesome bourbon barreled stout and no discernible drop in quality with the increased quantity and distribution.  Bottled August 2013.

2013 - 14.2% ABV  Pours black. Pitch black with a bit of brown foam if poured hard enough. The head quickly fizzles out, but what can you expect from such a high ABV beer? Huge aroma of chocolate, caramel, vanilla, a touch of smoke, dark rich sugars, licorice, and dark fruits. Intense and complex, the huge roasted malts and oak character manage to hide the alcohol quite well in the aroma. Taste follows similarly. Chocolate, vanilla, caramel, dark fruits. Very sweet. A slight burn on the end from being a young beer with a high abv. Incredibly thick and rich, low carbonation.  One huge stout. Love it.

Starting with appearance... this is the epitome of what a stout should look like. Pours absolute, sheer black, thick and like crude oil with a thin brown head. Zero light comes through even with a 600 Lumen flashlight on the other side of the glass. BLACK. At the very edges, it has a golden hue as opposed to the more common black with a reddish hue. Good lookin beer. Smell is well... bourbon... And lots of it. Bourbon, mild coffee, chocolate and coconut. Like a Mounds Bar... soaked in bourbon. The taste is simply incredible: robust but smooth bourbon comes first with the oak and vanilla you would expect. Bright notes of roasted coffee, molasses, vanilla and chocolate linger well after you finish your sip. The booze is very apparent, but not undesirable. This is a warmer; you feel it in your gut! Feel is heavy, thick but silky smooth. Almost zero carbonation. Coats your mouth and everything else on the way down leaving a boozey warmth wherever it touches. Fantastic beer overall; tons of good flavors, a perfect dessert or sipping beer, and it's affordable to boot. A must try.

Update: 2014 more char and chocolate, less bourbon. Side BY side blind: 2013 was still hotter, thicker, pungent   Short and sweet: first BCS ever  A- pitch black with red hues around the top  S- molasses, bourbon, vanilla and wet leather  T-ginger raisin molasses whiskey  M- thick yet cohesive , the posterior palate enjoys the light, vibrant carbonation  0 - heavy, dark, brooding. Up the Hammers.

Poured into a tulip glass via bottle  Color is blacker than black  Smell is heavy bourbon up front, followed by vanilla, chocolate, coffee, dark fruit, some oakiness..a lot going on here!  Taste is that bourbon blast up front, and chocolate and vanilla right behind..pretty boozy for sure, but its so damn smooth you dont care  Mouthfeel is very thick, coats the mouth nicely  Definitely a gold ribbon beer and one of my favorites for sure. I remember drinking this for the first time and being blown away that a beer could taste like this and have so much depth and character!

Appearance- Pours thick and black with a 1 finger tan head that recedes to a small covering on top. Just a little lacing.  Smell- Roasted malts with a bit of astringency. Some chocolate and licorice with a bit of dark fruits in the background. The smell is much more balanced and pleasant as it ages.  Taste- Very good taste. Milk chocolate, some black coffee, vanilla, a slight woody flavor and a noticeable but not overwhelming amount of bourbon.  Mouthfeel- Great mouthfeel and carbonation. It is extremely creamy and smooth. My first thought was its like drinking a fluffy cloud.  Overall- A great bourbon stout. The bourbon isn't as strong as some others that I have had but it is a great compliment to the stout. I will say this is a much better beer as it ages. The smell and flavor really develop with 1+ years on it.

look at all the reviews today! everybody got their release yesterday, chilled 'em, and are drinkin' 'em right now! I hate the hype, but this time it is warranted, I have to say, my very first one last night was one of the VERY BEST I have ever had. I went after the Abyss, and Butte, and several others; but this one is worth the hype! twelve full ounces. not 11. not 11.2. not 12.5. but good old-fashioned American 12. even the bottle feels heavy picking it up. perfect amount of bourbon aroma. no overpowering pseudo chocolate, or coffee to cover any potential imperfections.... viscous, but not overly thick. syrup-y, but not gaggingly so. super nice sweetness at the very end. and 14%. wow. knowing that AB or InBev (or whoever the heck they are) took over was a little disconcerting. I had heard so much about this stuff and figured they would change the ingredients, go cheap or just short-change everybody but I am very happily surprised. I place this one at the very top of my list, among the other excellent brews that are just a notch above the very good ones. the flavor hits me the most as it goes down my throat and leaves a thin coating of sweetness. this review lacks the adjectives and descriptions but that is only because it is all already covered by so many others today. my bottle says bottled on Aug 20 and is 14.2%. even the thick label gives it some personality. two down, two to go... and still in the hunt for more... I feel disappointed in myself for awarding such high scores to so many others in the past. this one is definitely there. add: 12/31/15 hate the new label and the new bottle. and HATE that it is SO SALTY..... what have they done with 2015's version?

Definitely one of my very favorites so happy to get it in Ct.  Awesome brew so glad nothings changed with InBev kudos to them for sticking with something that works great!  Not much more to say. I love it. Strongly recommend it. It's a bit pricey but worth it and good money to spend!

My first Bourbon County Brand Stout. Looking forward to this. Bought three 4 packs, planning on aging one.  Poured from a bottle into a pint glass.  A- pour a jet black and slowly develops a quiet coffee-and-cream head. Light lacing, head fades soon after pouring.  S- Like taking a shot of some straight Kentucky bourbon. Great amounts of vanilla and caramel, lighter amounts of dried fruit. Slightest amount of smoke comes in before the booze closes it strong.  T- Much like the smell, the caramel and vanilla from the bourbon hit up front. Dates and figs are present, and a lot of black coffee. The alcohol is present in a perfect way. a silky dark chocolate malt finishes strong.  M- Thick, smooth, velvety. light carbonation coats the tongue. Makes for the perfect sip.  O- Blown away. Not much else to say... One of the best beers I have had, and will absolutely be seeking this out for years to come.

2013 batch  A: As dark as it gets. Dark tan frothy head. Carbonation on the sides just keep going.  S: Right off the bat there's a lot of bourbon going on, oak, chocolate, a bit of vanilla, and definitely some booze.  T: Chocolate, bourbon, oak, dried fruit all immediately hit the palate. Finishes with some vanilla and coconut along with a bit of a warmth from the booze. 14.2% abv will do that.  M: Very bold. You definitely have to be used to/want this kind of heaviness from the flavors. It feels sticky in the finish.  O: Excellent beer. VERY robust. One is more than enough for a night. It'll be a while before I touch another. It's a very impressionable beer.

12 oz. bottle, with bottled on date October 11, 2013 printed on the back label. Ah yes, at long last I have finally acquired a bottle of the legendary Goose Island Bourbon County Brand Stout. Infinitely stoked to finally have this bottle, I have been waiting for this moment my entire life it seems. Every beer moment from now on will probably just be insignificant. My bottle lists a 14.90% abv.  Poured into a clear balloon snifter.  A - Pours a thick viscous oil slick black. Barely any conjuration of head, but creates a nice quarter inch of dark chocolate head when swirled in the glass. Bit of alcohol lacing sticks to the glass momentarily, but then falls. Looks truly amazing.  S - Smell is truly amazing also. So much going on. Beautiful vanilla. Cream. Caramel. Toasted oak wood. Alcohol fumes. Rum soaked raisins. Dates. Figs. Creamy chocolate. So rich, so complex.  T - Beautiful creamy vanilla. Silky milk chocolate. Bourbon alcohol warmth, but never too much. Some bitter coffee bean on the finish. Faint tart prune / raisin / date taste. Caramel. Hints of toasted coconut. This is some seriously next level type shit.  M - Feel is smooth, creamy, & silky. It rolls over your tongue like a cloud with a faint impression of whiskey / bourbon heat and some chocolate lingering on the finish.  Overall, an epic, beautiful beer from every angle. Everything I hoped it would be, in all honesty. So rich, so big, so complex. Very glad I managed to get this one this year; I cannot wait to try the other variants. Highly recommended deliciousness.  Goose Island Bourbon County Brand Stout ---5/5.

It poured thick with no lace on glass  The chocolate smell was prevalent in glass.  Very smooth to the palate. No bitterness or aftertaste. The bourbon taste explodes upon swallowing.  One of the best stouts that I have ever had. I can't imagine how this would be if aged a year or two.  Wish I could enjoy throughout the year.

Poured from a 12oz bottle into a Maudite tulip. Bottled 8/20/13, 2013 vintage (14.2%). Bought at Bevmo Costa Mesa CA for $23.99 a 4pk.  A - Black as motor oil. Light mocha head leaves decent lacing.  S - Lots of bourbon, vanilla, coconut. As well as, dark fruits (dried cherries, blueberries, figs, dates). A little tobacco.  T - Great mix of chocolate, vanilla, coconut, dried cherry, dried blueberry, and vanilla. Alcohol is present, but not overwhelming (especially for a 14% brew). A lighter version (less boozy) of Black Tuesday. Very nice.  M - Thick and rich as expected. Perfect. Carbonation is medium low. Very complimentary.  O - Everything you want in a BB Imp Stout. Great mix of chocolate, bourbon, and booze notes. Age will probably make this even better. Smoothing out some of the harsh alcohol notes.

A deep viscous brownish black as i poured with some hints of deep wine red around the rim. Huge legs deep khaki brown head dissipates almost instantly.  S bourbon soaked sweetness. Pungent. Could prob get buzzed just smelling this thing  T more of that bourbon sweetness. Its not as hot as I thought it would be based on other reviews but the alcohol is present and you absolutely feel it going down. Clearly a sipper its perfectly sweet.  M chewy. excellent. just a touch of carbonation. Its a bit sticky which I'm not a fan of thus the slight deduction.  O I'm of the mindset that most beers are best fresh but I could see how this would age really well. A really well crafted beer.

Poured from a 12oz. bottle into a tulip glass. Bottled on 08/29/13 14.9% ABV  A- Pours a think used motor oil black with a small dark brown sugar colored head that has to fight through the beer to form. The head dissipated to nothing very quickly but would come back on swirling and leaving quickly again. This beer clings to the glass amazingly.  S- Vanilla, bourbon, and dark dried fruits, nice buttery toffee all in perfect balance and all at big levels. I'm almost afraid to drink it because I don't want it to go away. Some ABV but not 14.9%'s worth.  T- This is one of the smoothest high ABV I've had. Much of the aroma but turned up and with a wonderfully Imperial stout finish. There is more ABV in the nose than in the taste. Oak, vanilla, dark roast, dark dried fruits. Alright after about an hour of warming up the ABV is coming through more and warming the throat. Still a pretty smooth high ABV beer.  M- Nice thick consistency, coats the mouth nicely. Not a lot of carb, but that is to be expected.  O- First time having this and went out on Black Friday to make sure I got some. Wish their was a little bit more head retention that I found in Black Note, kinda takes away from appearance for me. But that really is the only knock on it for me. Great balanced bourbon flavor and the stout coming through in the finish is pretty great as well. This is a lot of beer and probably one of the most concentrated in flavor beers I've had, it actually took me a while to drink the whole bottle. Splitting a bottle with a friend is actually a good idea, at least for me.

Poured from a 12 fl ounce bottle into a Goose Island chalice.  Appearance: Rich dark brown, heck, nearly black body. Very thin bubbly light-brown head formed and did not linger.  Nose: Bourbon galore! Whiskey hits the nostrils hard. Sweet caramel and chocolate follow. Almost smells like someone decided to add a respectable amount of whiskey to a batch of brownies.  Taste: Pretty remarkable taste. Much like the nose, the bourbon is the first thing I tasted. The hops travel very well with the bitter taste of alcohol. The bourbon taste wears out and very tasty notes of chocolate and caramel break through. Toasted, almost burnt malts create somewhat of a smokey backdrop. The high carbonation makes this feel tangy and leaves a bitter finish.  Overall: I am still fairly new to the craft brew scene, in fact, this was my first Bourbon County Stout ever! It was great to meet fellow enthusiasts outside the liquor store as we stood in line. I'll be honest, this beer has an incredibly bold flavor. I was almost too overwhelmed after the first few sips. The taste is incredible, you just have to enjoy whiskey.  There is a ton of hype around these releases and I feel as though it was worth the rather high price and effort I put into locking down a pack of these. I hope I can restrain myself from digging into the four-pack I stuck in my basement to age...

2014 poured from fridge temp in June of 2017. Jet black - no carbonation. Nose is bourbon, chocolate, coffee, molasses. Taste is so freaking smooth. Sweet bourbon, coffee, vanilla, maple syrup, marshmallow. So smooth. Mouthfeel is one of the best. Thick and creamy. Overall an amazing beer.

A - Dark as night with a small, reddish head that dissipates quickly.  S - Pretty much smells like straight bourbon.  T - At first, you get that boubony, hoppy taste with hints of chocolate. Then, you get a much stronger chocolate taste in the aftertaste.  M - Very smooth mouthfeel. Goes down with no problem.  Overall - It's a great beer. Very simple.

A: poured from bottle, settles very clean with no head, minimal residual bubbles on periphery of surface. Very dark in color, opaque.  S: smell of bourbon is quite evident, with hints of molasses and chocolate.  T: complex blend of chocolate, molasses and a tiny burn(In a good way!)  M: a whoosh spreading outward from tip of tongue with a hearty feel.  O: a delightful sipping beer paired excellent with a pecan pie!

A 2013 bottle poured into a Trillium tasting tulip.  Appearance: Jet black motor oil. Hints of coffee brown around the edges. No head, but a tiny eggshell crown.  Smell: Boozy, nutty. Hints of coffee and hazelnuts, lots of sweet dark chocolate.  Taste: Dark chocolate and hints of coffee. Thick and dark, roasty. When I opened this the day of release I remembered a decent amount of orange. Don't get any of that right now. Sweet but with a few hints of bitterness.  Mouthfeel: Thick and sticky. Lower carbonation. Perfect for the style.  Overall: There isn't a whole lot to say about this beer that hasn't already been said. It's a fantastic barrel aged stout.

Pours like 40 Weight, black as night, incredibly syrupy, and dense, lots of semi-sweet chocolate, BOURBON, rum, pecan praline, dried figs, dates, raisins, currant, and a touch of prune, extremely sweet, but never cloying, and dried out a bit by a welcome touch of coffee bitterness in the endless finish. Overall, very portlike...my new all-time favorite Impy!

A: Very dark, with a thin, light tan head.  S: Bourbon, a little toasty, malty. And bourbon.  T: More bourbon, some toffee, chocolate, oak. Some booziness. Lots of layers, a lot going on, but comes together very well.  M: Lightly carbonated. Smooth, full-bodied.  O: An excellent barrell aged stout. Lots of flavors that all come together well with a nice bourbon, oaky flavor. Don't sleep on this one - if you see it, buy it.

Poured from the 12 oz. bottle into an Innis & Gunn flute.  a: Black with just a hint of ruby at the bottom when seen through light, thin tan head disappeared quickly to just a few hints of lacing.  s: Bourbon  t: Bourbon and dark malt up front. Puckers the back of the mouth, and alcohol burn on the way down, no surprise given the highest ABV I have ever had in beer (15%). Slightly fruity finish.  m: Medium to heavy, smooth except for the aforementioned tendency for the sides of the back of the mouth to pucker, and the raging alcohol burn on the way down.  o; Packs a wallop of bourbon, dark malt and alcohol. More substance and less dominant bourbon flavor to it than the only other bourbon flavored beer I have had, Alltech's Kentucky Bourbon Barrel. Pretty overpowering. I can see why it is so highly rated. Still, if I want bourbon flavored beer, I think I'll go with something less lethal, not to say a helluva lot cheaper.  UPDATE 11/29/14: 2014 regular BCBS was delayed but a local store put out some 2012 on Black Friday to satisfy demand. Let's see how it fared.  a: Poured an oily opaque black with a thin head of unusually large bubbles which disappeared fairly quickly. Poured into a Unibroue stemmed flute.  s: Strong bourbon.  t: Bourbon and intense dark chocolatey malt. Alcohol burns the throat. Later the bourbon flavor dominates more completely.  m: Medium to full, oily, quite a bit of carbonation tingle.  o: Unique and outstanding! Definitely a slow sipper, a real boozy powerhouse that will never be accused of being watery. Bought some 2014 today and will do a comparison with this and 2013 very soon!  UPDATE 11/26/18: The last two years I was unable to find any, but 2018 is in hand. ABV now up to 14.7%. It's now $13-14 for half a liter (2015 was $10). More powerful than ever with a brown head which disappeared quickly. Not much aroma but lots of bourbon flavor. Medium mouthfeel seems a bit lighter than I remember (still have some 2014 I have one of every few months or so, but then that has aged and may be heavier than it was originally). it's still unique, and although not noticeably better than previous years, the experience I've gained since then requires giving BCBS more credit than I have in the past.

12 oz bottle poured into a pint glass. Bottled on 8/29/13. Consumed on 11/28.  A - Pours thick, almost black in color. Half finger of deep cinnamon colored head which quickly dissipates. Strong initial carbonation, but quickly fades.  S - Intensely fragrant. Bourbon, vanilla, dark fruit, and dark chocolate.  T - Very flavorful. Bourbon, dark chocolate, espresso, and brown sugar. Bourbon well balanced with other flavors. No doubt this is a big beer, but not a glass of bourbon... it's a stout with bourbon tones. Very warming and slightly peppery from higher alcohol content. However, despite ~15% ABV, it's not an alcohol bomb. You know it's there, and it's definitely a slow drinking beer, but it is not overwhelming by any means.  M - Silky with very nice carbonation. Thick, but not overly sticky.  O - No surprises here... it's as good as advertised. Love it.

A-Cmon, a top 250 stout...Appearance is perfect. S- Dark fruits, chocolate, and booziness in that order. T- Phenomenal. It's so well rounded. After the vanilla, chocolate, and caramel pass, there is a distinct booziness bite, but it is great. I wish I had 5 gallons. M- For a powerful stout, the body is nice and light bodied. O-Can't say I've had a better bourbon barrel aged stout. Parabola is the only one is beat it on shear taste.

2013 bottle poured into oversized snifter. Almost jet black, appears to have the consistency of oil but darker. Minimal head, but lacing nonetheless.  Scent of figs, vanilla then wood and of course, bourbon. A little dry sting to the nostrils.  Taste of oak, vanilla, bourbon, dried dark fruit, cocoa nibs. Finish is very oaky and bourbony but balanced with sweetness. Alcohol is present, but goes smoothly over the palate.  A tad bitter, but a nice balancing sweet finish. Viscous and a bit chewy.  Overall, very balanced, and as smooth as a beer this strong can be. This is really the only beet I've had that deserves the word bourbon in the name. Not just a hint of bourbon, they did it right. The only thing that could really make this better would be cold steeped coffee, and they have a beer for that.

Black with the slightest head foam. Bourbon probably killed it.  Charred, almost burned, strong notes of bourbon.  Bourbon, no doubt, and what's closer to dark chocolate than coffee. Simplistic that way. Rich and sweet, kinda like liquid toffee. Anymore burn on the back would be a bother. Has that leather and tobacco to go with the sweet fruit.  Dense and sticky, the carbonation's as light as can be.

Huge thanks to tdadiuk for sending me this beer, huge want.  A: Pours an exceptionally idnight black colour with minimal espresso tinted head which completely dissipates leaving.  S: Amazing scents of bourbon, cocoa, espresso, roasted malts together with hints of toffee and alcohol esters.  T: Follows the scent, with sweet milk chocolate, espresso, roasted malts, bourbon and alcohol esters. Incredibly smooth and finishes with slight bitterness notes of espresso and alcohol.  M: Full bodied and creamy.  O: Definitely lives up to its reputation, this is an incredible stout that I am thankful that I had the opportunity to try.

2013 poured into a snifter. Vigorous pour raised a tiny bit of barrel colored head, dissipated quickly. Black as night. Beautiful.  Smell of bourbon, with hints of vanilla, smoke, dark fruit.  Taste is overwhelmingly complex. Vanilla, coffee, char, prune/fig and bourbon. Finishes like a good port...sweet heat,  Mouthfeel is straight from heaven, perfect amount of carbonation, creamy but not cloying.  This is the gold standard of bourbon barrel aged stouts. Many beers cant live up to this amount of hype, this does. Glad I have a stockpile!

So this review will be for the 12oz, 2013 edition of 14.2% ABV bottled on 04SEP13 poured into an Innis & Gunn snifter. I managed to find a 4 pack of it from the beer store up the road for $22.99. Seems a bit much, but considering that breaks down to less per bottle than Chimay, I'll call it a bargain...  A: First off, I like the packaging- Even that has a matured, well thought out feel to it, printed on high quality paper... Pours black with a slight reddish tint and has a dark tan head of about one finger that recedes quickly and leaves no lacing. A swirl of the glass and it coats all sides in a viscous amber ribbon.  S: Definitely picking up the bourbon, caramel, vanilla, oak, chocolate and maybe a bit of smoked peat like a good Wee Heavy Scotch Ale. Not picking up on any hops or abrasively overpowering alcohol- Just pure, sweet Bourbon Imperial Stout.  T: Now for the big one- I took a sip, and without the flavor even registering yet, I was smiling... In a word, it's amazing- All of the aromas that were there, are amplified in the taste. Thankfully, It wasn't as sweet as I was expecting, The coffee flavor gives way to charred oak and vanilla-caramel as the dominant notes. There's just barely an alcohol note at the very end that warms as it goes down.  M: Not quite as thick as it looks, and there's almost no carbonation to speak of- Nothing that particularly stands out about the style. Nothing unpleasant either though. There's no astringency that I can tell, and I'd say that's impressive for something this strong, bottled so recently.  O: In summation, this beer absolutely lives up to the hype. It may not be my perfect beer, but it's damn close... The Smell is the pinnacle of this beers showcase, while it's appearance and mouth-feel leave something to be desired. It was definitely a good purchase, and I look forward to the next bottle. I'd highly recommend this one to anyone who likes beer, bourbon and new experiences...

I am enjoying my second consecutive bottle of this 2009 Bourbon County which was bottled on 01142010. I Cellared them for 2 years and then stored in my Bros beer cave in his liquer store till a couple of weeks ago. I brought them 1600 miles through a range of temps and today they arrr warming in the glass to an ambient temp of 84.  I give such high marks because this stuff is in a class of it's own. It "develops in the bottle for up to 5years". There is no real pecedence after this long and i can only tell you i am enjoying it thoughy.  I have two still in storage that I will try next year.:-)  Poured into a glass, naturally.

One of the better Stouts out there. Again with some age on it. This beer in my opinion is actually bad fresh. It needs at least 2-5 years of age. I have had this beer in vertical tastings many times and it is so much better with age. It takes all of the alcohol off of it. It is just way to hot fresh. But if you have the patience wait because it is one of the best out there.

Had on tap at whole foods Columbus circle- pours a thick black color with minimal head, retention, and lacing. Keeps a ring of foam around the edge. Served in a pint glass.  Smell is not strong- a hint of caramel/bourbon evenly blended with some dark roasted malt and a little booze. Nothing to blow you over.  Taste is far more interesting. Sweet bourbon taste, some roasted malts (coffee, a little milk chocolate). This is pretty sweet. Not really a noticeable hop presence but it must be there because the sweetness isnt out of control.  Mouthfeel is pretty nice- full bodied, light carbonation, a little chewy. This is one I've heard about so I had to try it. Worth a try, perhaps not a second.  Update: I've aged a few bottles of the 2012 variety and just had one- sickeningly sweet, cloying mouthfeel. Still not a fan; don't understand the hype. Too sweet, no carbonation or bitterness to make it drinkable in the slightest. Anyone want my other bottles?

2012 bottle. Enjoyed to get ready for the new batch.  Preface: I believe nothing can be perfect, but this is dang close.  A. Extremely dark brown, almost black. Poured a finger amber head of fine bubbles that rapidly retreat to a rim of similar color and consistency. A very viscous texture and leaves an amber layer on the edges of the glass when swirled.  S. At first a layer of dark roasted malts, coco, bourbon, coffee malts, bourbon, boozey-soaked oak, and tannins. Slight roasted - not burnt - note. As it opens, sweeter notes of vanilla, toffee, coconut and a high level of booze. The booze increases as it opens - in a pleasant way.  T. Strong notes of bourbon, coffee, coco, and roasted malts. Moderate notes of boozey oak and tannins. Hints of vanilla, hazelnuts, and toffee. As this ale opens, the bourbon and roasted malt notes dominate the other notes.  M. Extremely smooth but a moderate waft of booze comes through as you finish a sip. Low carbonation. Full bodied. Thick. The booze finish becomes slightly harsh as the ale gets close to room temperature.  O. Almost perfect. This ale is great. I let this stand at room temperature from the fridge for about 20 minutes - which was very difficult as I am not a patient person. I savored this ale for almost and hour. The beer changed smell, taste, and feel profiles as it opens and warms. I would go to great lengths for this particular beer.

My favorite stout... perhaps my favorite beer for 2013. Do not pair this with anything and for heavens sakes do not drink this with a meal. Enjoy this from a sniffter glass. You can also finish a bottle days after opening it. I typically buy these in 4s when I see them which is once or twice a year.

2012 bottling year of Goose Island's Bourbon County Stout. This beer has a bit of a cult following but is getting easier to find nowadays. I've had it on tap and thought it was a bit too boozy for my tastes so I was curious to see what a year would do for the bottled variety. The smell is the best part about this beer when you pour it out. Black as night and a minimal amount of toffee colored head which quickly dissipates. The sweet bourbon and chocolate aroma is amazing. Initial sip starts with rich, almost milk chocolate with a tinge of booze. Much better than the alcohol smash of having a fresh glass. Then comes the problem, the beer is simply too darn sweet. The mid-taste profile of this beer is complex for sure with chocolate, vanilla, coconut hints and LOTS of bourbon which I love, but darn is it sugary too. It reminds me almost of the sweet tooth smack of a vintage port wine. It's not undesirable, but just really unbalanced in what is otherwise a really darn good brew. Overall, a 4.5 and a very good beer that is worth seeking out, but I hope you have that sweet tooth! I prefer the bitter, thick chocolate flow of KBS over this, but it is still a tasty beverage.

12 ounce bottle poured into a small snifter. 2012 vintage. No carbonation, clear, sticky lacing. Aroma includes toasted malt, whiskey, port, maple, alcohol. Taste includes all of the above but the alcohol is well hidden. Some molasses as well. Amazing blend of flavor and truly a masterpiece.
Bottled and bottle conditioned Bottled and part of a big order from beers of Europe to celebrate my 40th birthday full on coffee and bourbon and chocolate boozy experience
The standard all BA Stouts are judged. This beer is fantastic with great bourbon on the nose and taste yet fudgy stoutness (especially when aged a couple years) that smooths everything out.

Served in 12 oz bottle. Had a three pack of the 2012 version. Aging one.  A - Amazing looking creamy beer with minimal carbonation. Dark as night. 15% abv makes this one a monster.  S - Can smell the bourbon, the coffee, the chocolate, cloves, licorice, slight carmel hints  T - Liked the first bottle I had more than the second, not sure why, maybe just the mood I was in. First one I had though was incredible. Minimal carbonation, coconut, vanilla, chocolate, coffee. Slight alcohol burn that may level out as my 3rd bottle ages.  M - Full bodied. Creamy deliciousness with a strong booze finish.  O - Can't wait to compare this and the 2010 bottle OF BCBS Coffee that I have aging. Loved this beer and stands up there with the greats. The hype did not surpass this beer.  Will get my hands on more in the future. Would like to try another year though.

2012 vintage:  A: opaque black. Extremely low carbonation. Medium-to- medthick body. S: Cloves, licorice, caramel, and the obvious whisky barrel. T: Licorice, clove, wood, sweet toffee, a pinch of cordial cheery. M: Not a chewy as you would expect. I'm happy with that. Actually, quite drinkable O: I usually go for bourbon aged beers as I don't drink bourbons. This picks up really nicely. Lots of licorice become more present as it warms. Helping to change me opinion on GI.

2008 Bourbon County Brand Stout  A: Deep black, hardly any carb  S: Heaven. Such rich intense aromas of bourbon, chocolate and oak  T: The first sip validated what all the hype is about - this beer tastes phenomenal. Huge bourbon, chocolate, oak, vanilla and espresso flavors. Incredibly easy to drink  M: So thick, so good  O: I enjoyed the 2008 more than 2012 or 2013 which are the only others I've had. All great but the 2008 was special

Best InBev beer out there. By far my favorite beer on tap. I don't care how many times I've had it, if it's on tap, I'm buying it. Most recently I had a 10 oz. at Sunset in Allston, MA. It's always there, and I dont know how often it rotates out but I have to say it never loses it's amazingness, I'm currently aging a bottle I bought last year the day my son was born and look forward to cracking it open on his 1st birthday.... just buy it.

Bourbon County isn't really a beer so much as it is a recruitment tool for the craft beer movement.  There is nothing like giving a 6oz pour to a beer newbie and seeing the expression on their face when they taste a SERIOUS beer for the first time. The complexity and intensity experienced when Bourbon County enters your mouth rivals that of any wine or liquor, and you have no choice but to savor it.  The great thing about Bourbon County is that it was an intense beer before it was barrel-aged, so the bourbon flavor is an added benefit rather than an outsider trying to wrestle control.  WARNING: This beer will ruin most other imperial stouts for you. The only other stout that I've found that competes is the slightly-superior Dogfish Head World Wide Stout.  Pairing suggestion: Have Bourbon County with a piece of rich chocolate cake. I had it with a amazing piece that included peanut butter/cream cheese frosting and it was probably the best thing my taste buds have ever encountered.

12oz single picked up on a trip to Denmark. Poured into a snifter. 2012 version (looks to have a drink by date of 08.10.13?)  A: Pours thick and viscous with very little foam; looks heavy; opaque black; no lace, as expected at 15%.  S: Indulgent aroma... black strap molasses; roasted malt; pie crust; bourbon barrel ooze... syrupy vanilla. Wife says it smells of soy sauce.  T: Charred malt; sticky bourbon sweetness / light oaky vanilla; molasses and dark fruit; dark chocolate; a touch of smoked malt, too. Wow.  M: Full; moderate carbonation; quite sticky on the palate; a sweet, big beer for sure.  O: An unbelievably smooth barrel aged imperial stout (especially at 15%!); very sweet - more so that expected - perhaps because of age. Quite a belly warmer and way tasty!

Poured Bourbon County into a Belgian Tulip.  A - The black brew is black as midnight with a skim of dark mocha head.  S - Vanilla, butterscotch, light whiskey, maybe a hint of char. Looking forward to this baby.  T - Heavy bakers chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, sugar sweetness. It has even more vanilla mid palate. Milk chocolate with more vanilla and a touch of char on the aftertaste. This flavor finishes long and smooth. It does have alcohol in this one because you can feel the warming in your chest, but you can't taste it.  M- Thick and smooth, light to medium carbonation. No complaints here.  O - A very nice beer to sip and enjoy for the evening. At 15 percent its a one and done. Cheers!

Cracked a 2012 vintage tonight. Jet black and the minimal head quickly dissipates. Intense aroma of bourbon greets me from a foot away. As I get closer I get black licorice, molasses, roasted barley and a lingering sweetness from the bourbon. The mouthfeel is thick and sticky. Plum, raisins, roasted barley, and then the burning warmth of the alcohol coat the tongue and gently warm your throat.

2008, 2011, and 2012 bottles side by side  2008 is pure fudge if cellared properly. This beer was incredible. It was almost better than Bramble. The body is so full and rich. There is absolutely no heat at all. Huge chocolate on the nose and just rich fudgey flavor. 2011 was rich and full of bourbon flavor with some chocolate and some roastiness. The mouthfeel was a little slicker. More bourbon on the nose and some heat on the tongue. 2012 pales in comparison to those but it's still a great beer. You get even more heat on the tongue but a similar nose. The bourbon is full and lively, which mutes the body flavors a bit like coffee, chocolate, and vanilla.  If you purchase enough BCBS and cellar it properly, you'll have your own personal variants in a few years. What a fun and complex beer. I blame no one for trading for older BCBS as long as they trust the cellaring.

2012 bottle  Jet black and fairly dense looking with a ring of small tan head and no lace at all. Smell is loaded with bourbon, oak and vanilla, bakers chocolates, fudge, incredible roast qualities, a bit of alcohol heat, light coffee as well, an incredible nose in every way. Taste is similar to the nose, roasted malts and bourbon, vanilla, oak, various chocolate flavours, fudge-chocolate chip cookie flavours, a little heat from the alcohol, more bourbon in the aftertaste. Lightly carbonated, big full bodied chewey feel. Just incredible every bit as good as I had anticipated but I still enjoyed BCBCS more, wonderful stuff here.

2012 Vintage poured into snifter.  Pours a very very dark brown. Thick as hell. Looks like dirty motor oil. Very minimal head but not much expected at 15%  Smell is bourbon and sweet malts. Some dark fruits and hints of bitter coffee. Some vanilla and oak come through as well. A definite char.  Taste is magnificent. Syrupy sweetness with a bit of milk chocolate. Vanilla. Oak. Huge malts and bourbon flavors. Ugh. Just phenomenal. Char and deep burnt caramel. It just goes on and on. Molasses and more.  Mouthfeel is massive. Just the right amount of carbonation. Huge and chewy. Almost like syrup.  This beer is near perfect for me. You've heard of it. Get it.

Goose Island Beer Co. - (2011) Bourbon County Brand Stout, poured into a Craftgeer snifter.  Look - Pours a thick oil black with no real head about it, but it's aged in who knows what conditions (got it from a friend) so I'm not going to split hairs here. Lacing is little chunks all over the glass.  Smell - Rich and creamy sweet chocolate and caramel with blended bourbon on top. Absolutely delectable.  Taste - Carbonated bite, then creamy chocolate and coffee with a bite of bourbon at the end. Sweet caramel and molasses lingers on the tongue.  Mouthfeel - Rests thick and sweet, but not too sweet. It's a friggan dessert by itself! Obviously boozy but surprisingly drinkable. Fullest of full bodied. Moderate to high carbonation that works well.  Overall - This is phenomenal. I can't pour InBev haterade on this one, it's great. 100% recommend.

update: 2012 cellared for one year. Stronger, more complex chocolate aroma. Nutty aroma becomes apparent with warming. The nutty aroma morphs into an oak aroma- from the barrels.  The taste is very complex chocolate- it's more layered than the fresh bottle. There is a nutty taste, which is also more pronounced when fresh.  The Bourbon alcohol finish kicks in with warming. There is a liqueur consistency which is slightly stronger than the fresh tasting.  A great beer-fresh or cellared.  *** Fresh review  It's time. Got another bottle in the cellar.  2012: Poured a deep, opaque chocolate brown with virtually no head.  Very strong Bourbon, alcohol, and a nutty flavor wafted from the head. It's intense already!  The mouth feel was relatively smooth, like the other elements of the beer. It may be a high ABV Imperial stout with pronounced aroma and flavor- but it's smooth- no harshness to this baby.  The aroma carries to the taste- slightly different. Incredibly intense Bourbon and alcohol- smooth but intense- some fruit and nuts.  This beer tastes like a liqueur- highly alcoholic & smooth. Rounded intensity.  Amazing Imperial Stout.

2012 version poured from 12oz bottle into a tulip , midnight black beer with a 3 finger deep brown head that goes away pretty fast and small amounts of lacing  Wow , the nose on this is something special , picking up on the sweet malt , some vanilla to go along with the bourbon aroma , just mouth watering  The mouth on this beer is the best I've had for the style , nice and thick and filling with just the right amount of carbonation  The taste is out of this world good a mixture of sweet malt and the bourbon mixing together with some vanilla in the background and and a nice little alcohol burn at the end.  Overall this beer got my first complete 5 across the board , I really didn't think it would live up to the hype I've seen about it , but it did , it actually blew it out of the water , if you have not got to try this beer yet , do what it takes to get yourself some , it really is a gem

Couldn't be any blacker. Little beads of carbonation are only visible on the edge of the glass rising in constant streams. Two finger thick head is the color of coffee and cream. Head dissipates after a minute or two leaving only a thin top.  Powerful aroma, filled with notes of vanilla, soy sauce, metallic, oak, bourbon. Smells quite alcoholic.  Wow, this is very full bodied. Huge flavor. The body is soft and smooth as cream. Flavors of deeply roasted grains, cherry cordial, sweet caramel, and bourbon soaked oak chips. This beer is amazing the way that it balances the massive body with just enough bitterness and booze. Long lasting aftertaste leaves the mouth with lingering notes of bourbon goodness and charred oak.  Isn't hard to see why this is one of the highest rated beers in the world. It's massively flavorful and integrates the bourbon with the big ass stout in a perfect way. The carbonation is flawless and helps to create a creamy texture, giving an ideal mouthfeel for a big stout like this one. The beer is never cloyingly sweet and is mildly hot, unlike some other massive beers I've tried before. I give it very high marks.

A - pours a thick oily black. The condensation on the glass gives it a slate look. Reminiscent of black top. Bubbly, fizzy deep tan foam, roughly a fingers worth rises up and then quickly dissolves.  S - the nose is decadent. Notes of warm gooey caramel and vanilla jump out. Toasted coconut shells, sandalwood, and peppery/alcohol notes round out the intense flavors. Classic stout characteristics lay underneath. French roast coffee, bakers chocolate and hints of dark dried fruits.  T - toasty, roasty and chocolate flavors collide on the front of the tongue. The chocolate flavors shine through momentarily until the bourbon-y, peppery heat comes out mid-palate. Intense flavors of caramel, wood, and vanilla all fight for attention. Hints of juicy dark fruits as well. Backend is more caramel, molasses, pepper and bourbon. Finish is surprisingly soft and sweet with a lingering boozey flavor.  M - milkshake thick. Creamy texture and full bodied. Medium-high carbonation. Just enough to keep this incredibly viscous liquid from becoming cloying.  O - one of the best barrel aged stouts money can buy.

2012 bottle  A: Totally black as one would expect. No light coming through at all. Dark brown head forms only briefly.  S: Big alcohol nose here, with whiskey and dark fruit coming in behind the booze.  T: With the first sip I immediately thought of it as whiskey-dipped fig and chocolate cake. I think that pretty much describes it. Dark fruits and chocolate blend pretty well and the bourbon flavors come in later. Pretty big alcohol even with the age on it. Aftertaste is dark fruit and low end whiskey. The chocolate becomes lost with further sipping.  M: Very thick and smooth. Excellent feel.  O: I like BCBS, but I don't love it. Flavors are nicely blended, but there isn't a lot of complexity. I prefer this aged bottle over my first one, which I had fresh. I'll probably let my last bottle keep aging and see if it merits purchase again.

Awesome beer.  A. Dark, very dark almost black. Small head, not much lacing.  S. Very strong bourbon scent. Sweet mocha taste that follows bourbon nicely and works beautifully.  T. Bourbon hits you right away. Once that passes the coffee takes over. The flavor is fantastic but strong.  M. Very full. The beer is thick and very smooth. Goes down easily.  O. This beer is great. The warmer it gets the better it is. Definitely get your hands on it ASAP.

Bottled 11/07/2012. Poured in to a tulip style glass.  Pours out thick and black like crude oil. There’s hardly any head, but the small amount that’s visible is a nice tan color. Lots of bourbon on the nose, milk chocolate, leather and booze. Very sweet and warming on the palate. There’s more bourbon, along with chocolate, coffee, leather, cabernet sauvignon grapes, prunes, and black currants…amazingly complex. Smooth and ridiculously creamy in the mouth, this drinks dangerously easy for its ABV. There’s a slight bitterness and also an interesting acidic quality that make all the flavors work together really well. Overall, I’m impressed by the depth and deliciousness of this stout.

Review #400 – Goose Island Bourbon County Brand Stout  Notes are a compilation of recent 2009 and 2012 samples - Received in trade from brooklynbrews – supreme thanks man!  12oz bottle with my FW snifter glass  A: Looks jet black in the glass with a slight browning towards the edge and a very short lived dark khaki head. Bubbles are lively and visibly streaming yet they struggle to retain any type of cap. The older version had produced virtually no head at all. Just a few minor dots of lace here and there noted.  S: Smells of roast coffee bean and dark malted syrups up front. Firm sweetness of molasses and toasted brown sugars mixed in with some vanilla oak, dark fruits, and bourbon aromas. There is a hint of alcohol spirit coming through in the nose and a touch of earthy black licorice on the back end. Very intoxicating with complex layers coming across. The ’09 version has calmed a bit with more of the black licorice coming through while still maintaining a nice vanilla bourbon barreling presence.  T: Tastes of sweet dark roasted malts highlighted with rich chocolates, molasses, dark fruits, bourbon vanilla, and some charred oak character. There is a bit of coconut marshmallow crème that is just a delight and a hit of brewers licorice as well. Adds a sort of earth and woodsy element to the brew. I am finding there to be a moderately higher level of hop bitterness to the beer and the alcohol has somewhat of a boozy sting to it. Manageable however at 15% ABV. The heat has mellowed considerably in the 2009 version offering up just a delicious bourbon cream soda flavor with loads of silky chocolate and toasted coconut character. A delicious blend of flavors all together with considerable balance. World class stuff!  M: Full bodied brew with a spritzy carbonation giving the perception of something lighter and thinner in mouthful. Creamy froth like texture with a light constricting bitterness and present alcohol warmth. Finish has a coat of syrupy slick after. Time has smoothed this one out quite a bit as the carbonation has dropped considerably to the point of approaching flatness.  D: Amazingly complex and simply delicious. This beer is undoubtedly special. One of the best barrel aged stouts I have yet to encounter. I would say after trying the ’09 it is reaching a point of diminishing returns based on the carbonation however the flavors have held up exceptionally well.  Glad I have a few more of these to sock away.

Vintage 2012.  The colour is dark brown, almost black (90 EBC), the liquid is clear. It pours very smooth and silently. Almost no head, just a few brown bubbles. No lacing.  The smell is rich and smooth. Sweet notes of raisins and figs. Some alcohol, but at 15 % is is much less pronounced than expected. Flavours of mature whiskey, caramel and dark chocolate. Hints of tobacco and dark rum.  The taste is intensive. Lots of dark chocolate, dark rum and toffee. Coffee with sugar and some cream. Bourbon whiskey, liquor filled truffles and crème brûlée. Full body, if there ever was one beer with that. The aftertaste got passing very hot alcohol. Then, it gets sweeter with notes of dark rum, bourbon, molasses, dried figs and a touch of smoke. The finish is quite short with alcohol, dried fruits and coffee with whipped cream.  The carbonation is mild; the few small bubbles are fresh. The liquid is thick and sticky, almost like drinking syrup.  Yes, it is a very elegant and smooth beer with lots of deep flavours. But the hype fooled me, or is it just that barrel aged imperial stouts have got even heavier and more complex during the years? Still, a great dessert beer.

12oz Bottle $19.99 4-Pack Sam's Marcey  2007 Bottling 13%  The '07 Bourbon County Stout pours black as a moonless night. Not a shred of light can fight its way through the blackness. An aggressive pour yields only a small crown of tan foam which is to be expected with the massive abv. The head settles to a ring and leaves patches of lace after each sip.  As you take your first whiff you're hit with a big dose of vanilla from the barrel aging. Traces of bourbon come next followed by a mellow oakiness. The barrel aging runs throughout but is greeted and embraced by a big roastiness, caramel maltiness, and a smattering of dark fruit. There's even a ghost-like smokiness floating around in there.  There is a great stout in here but the barrel aging makes it world class. All the qualities from the aroma are right here in the flavor with the bourbon, vanilla, and a touch of woodiness working throughout. If this beer was aged any longer the bourbon would overpower everything else, if it was aged any less the bourbon wouldn't have been able to stand up to such a big robust stout. This is a slice of heaven in a glass.  The mouthfeel is thick and rich but exquisitely smooth. The carbonation is on the sluggish side which lets this silky body glide through slowly and coats every taste bud. The alcohol warms the throat on the swallow.  I can't give a stout this big abv wise a perfect score for drinkability but this is as close as it could get. This is a slow sipper without a doubt but one to sip and savor all night long.  One of my favorites from Goose Island and one of my favorite stouts period. The barrel aging sets this beer apart from the other great stouts. Bourbon County Stout is absolutely delicious.

12oz 2012 bottle poured into a wine glass. Date on the bottle is smudged, but I think it reads 8/26/12.  A: Pours jet-black with a thin mocha head that dissipates quickly, leaving a tiny but stubborn ring of bubbles around the rim. Plentiful, wispy lacing with even slight movement of the glass.  S: ...hmm. Maybe I'm missing something here, but the initial nose is, well, pretty mediocre. Lots of boozy bourbon, with maybe some subtle coconut notes. The coconut becomes more pronounced as the beer warms, though, and notes of semisweet chocolate and espresso emerge alongside it. Definite improvement in the nose as the beer approaches room temperature.  T: Oh man. Oh MAN. A powerful wallop of bourbon right up front, with strong notes of aged oak and vanilla, that fades into a complex medley of other flavors--black liquorice, coffee, molasses, toffee, and chocolate all mingle together into a spectacular whole. Sweet and creamy for most of the mouthful, the bourbon announces itself again at the end with a touch of its signature burn and some lingering notes of espresso bitterness.  M: Thick and lip-coatingly creamy, with just enough carbonation to prevent the beer from being overpoweringly heavy-bodied. Still easily the most full-bodied beer I've ever had--warming and robust, with the 15% ABV announcing itself throughout.  O: I have to admit, when I first took a whiff of BCBS I was a little hesitant. After all the hype surrounding this beer, I was all too ready to expect disappointment somehow, and the initial nose did not give me confidence. I can happily report, however, that I was DEAD wrong, and delighted to have been so. A rich, robust beast of a beer that I would confidently put forward as a paragon of the BBA stout family. Not a light drinker, not a terribly easy drinker, not a sessionable beer in the least...but for what it is, it's simply spectacular.

A: Pitch black with a thin creme brulee colored head that quickly dissipates. When agitated you get thin whispy clouds of head floating in the beer. Very rich and thick with great lacing  N: Coconut! as it breaths you start getting more coffee as well, a bit boozy, Brandy, dark chocolate after it sits for a while  T: some heat from booze, lots of coconut, coffee, not dry at all which you'd expect from bourbon barrels, toffee, some caramel, finishes boozy  M: sticky, thick, rich, lingering  O: This has to be one of the most incredible Imp Stout's I've ever had. So much going on, so rich and powerful, and its pretty young too, I can't wait to see what adding a few years would do

12oz bottle into a tulip. 2012 bottle.  A - Hard pour yields minimal dark-tan/brown head, that seems rather effervescent for the style. Black as night in the glass. No head retention other than a thin dark ring around the glass. Also, one of the nicest labels in craft beer.  S - Immediately I can't decide if this smells more like bourbon or more like beer to my untrained nose. Aroma is all bourbon upfront, with big notes of oak, vanilla and a slight booziness. A base of roasted malt with some coffee and dark fruits is present but certainly secondary to the big bourbon quality. Lots of sweetness, with a touch of molasses as well as black cavendish. Not very astringent, with minimal hop presence. Respectably complex, but certainly geared towards the bourbon.  T - Huge bourbon qualities dominate the flavor profile. Oak barrel, bourbon vanilla, and the full force of the 15.00% ABV are immediately made known. Charred malt and molasses are detectable, and a lot of sweetness as well. Some earthy hops, bitter cocoa, black cavendish, and a whole lot of alcohol in the finish. To me this goes beyond "boozy warmth" or "slight heat", this is just a alcoholic burn in the finish, which kinda bums me out. The flavor is big, there's no denying that, but I can find this much flavor and more with much less ABV. That being said this is still great, and packs a huge wallop of flavor, and if you're looking for huge bourbon character in your beer, look no further.  M - Thick and quite creamy. Carbonation is lively but smooth. Sticky as can be on the lips, and the finish burns with booze. Par the course for a big stout, but nothing out of the ordinary.  D - A huge stout, that delivers and then some on the promise of bourbon flavor. But the substantial boozy heat and somewhat straight forward flavor doesn't quite do it for me. Maybe my expectations are too high coming into these reviews for big stouts, but I find them to sometimes be overly boozy and offer a one-dimensional barrel aged character. I taste bourbon and booze, but not a whole lot else, and they certainly don't offer a great deal of complexity. If I wanted a bourbon I'd have a bourbon. But, that being said, this is superb beer and to me pushes the envelope for how far craft beer, especially big stouts, can be taken. But if I had the chance to drink this everyday would I go for it? Probably not. Too much alcohol and residual sweetness for me. A late-night sipper but I certainly couldn't drink this often, and there's no way I could have more than one. A great beer, but as silly as it might sound, I'd take an Old Raspy over this 9 times outta 10.

Pours a very nice shade of dark chocolate into a tulip glass with a very thin tan head at the top. Aroma is a combination of malt, chocolate, bourbon and a little hint of vanilla. Taste is a great balance of flavor, masking the 15% alcohol content. Something to sip slowly but definitely an easy drink compared to what I expected. You feel that kick from the alcohol content after it goes down as you body suddenly feels much warmer.  Overall a very very good stout, look forward to having this again and hopefully the other versions

12oz bottle into an Olde Hickory snifter. 9/6/12 bottling date.  Pours a pitch black with a slight beige head that quickly dissipates. Smell is big on booze with some chocolate notes. The taste is very very smooth. Big alcohol taste but not overpowering, it's super easy to drink. I get some vanilla and chocolate and coffee notes exceptionally blended. You can definitely feel the kick to this one in your belly. Full bodied with low carbonation, but so creamy and an ease to drink. You COULD drink it fast if you chose, but savoring it is the way to go.  Overall an exceptional, world class bourbon barrel aged stout. I'd drink this everyday.

Bottle says 2012.  Poured thick and without any head. I get a thin ring when I tilt the glass and some alcohol legs. Nose is oaky, boozy, bourbon whiskey, smooth dark chocolate and some vanilla. Roasted malt and a bit of coffee. Tiny bit of dark fruit but I am actually glad that it's not too pruney with all the bourbon barrel qualities.  One very small sip to start and it's beer heaven. This a smooth roasted malt, deep full and rich like hot melted caramel. The bourbon is luscious and because it's hot from the alcohol has a sweet warmth. Dark creamy chocolate, buttery toffee, oak flavor and just a touch of raisin,prune and fig. it reminds me of english butter toffee candy that's coated with nuts and chocolate. It lingers like whiskey with a little burn at 15% abv and is full and smooth.  Thick and rich, creamy and decadent. This is no lightweight stout. Coats the palate and the back of the throat and is a terrific experience. I would have this anytime. Sip slowly as it's such a big beer. The complexity unfolds as it drinks.  Thank you Kerry. I feel lucky to have had the chance to try this.

330ml bottle served in a snifter glass.  2012 Edition. Bottled in 23.08.2012. Thanks to stevedore for bringing this one from US!  A: Pours an absolutely black color forming a minimal beige to brown head (and I've poured quite aggressively :)). Minimal retention and no lacings left  S: Absolutely delicious in the nose. Strong notes of oak and bourbon. Sweet candy. Vanilla and chocolate notes. Roasted malts. A bit booze  T: Sweet upfront followed by a roasted bitterness. Strong notes of oak, coffee, dark chocolate and bourbon. Licorice. Extremely creamy and molasses. Impressive. Good bitterness caused by roasted malts, mainly. Perfect taste  M: Heavy body. Extremely creamy and smooth: Impressive. Low carbonation. The thickest beer I've ever tried. Perfect body. Bittersweet aftertaste  O: Perfect drinkability. One of the best Imperial Stouts ever! No more comments...

2012 bottle in snifter, shared with a friend.  Appearance - Jet black, beige head disappears quickly  Smell - Smells fantastic, lots of Bourbon, coffee, vanilla, caramel, a hint of dark fruit.  Taste - Close to perfection. It's perfectly balanced between coffee, chocolate, vanilla and bourbon of course. Some hints of dark fruits. Alcohol is hidden very well. Perfect balance between sweet and bitter. Very easy to drink.  Mouthfeel - Thick, creamy yet very subtle.  Overall - One of the best BA stouts I've had, perfect balance, fantastic smell, great taste.

Re-review of the 2014 version (13.8% ABV):  BCBS has never really been about the smell, in my opinion; there's some stuff going on there, of course, but you get a lot of bourbon heat on the nose, which takes it down a notch for me. The fun is really when you get into everything else.  The beer pours like typical BCBS--Very thick, with only a little head (but what's there is a delightful coffee-brown color). Typical syrupy goodness, nothing new here.  However, the taste is different. Still BCBS? Sure. But this year, possibly due to the infamous Polar Vortex's influence on the barrel-aging process (the warehouse was too cold to use as normal, so GI had to keep heaters on the barrels, apparently), the beer is slightly more mellow than normal, and you get more vanilla on the tongue. Really impressive, and definitely my favorite version of the regular, to date.  This is typical BCBS; lots of bourbon, mouthfeel is thick as always, but the beer itself is a little more refined than normal. Great stuff here, and definitely worthy of the work it takes to land it. This is probably the first and last thing I'll thank the Polar Vortex for.

2013 bottle, pored into a glass you've never hear of.  Pours almost black, with dark brown edges. Modest finger of dense tan head sticks around for a good while.  Good lord, once it warms it smells like a artery clogging dessert; marshmallow, dark chocolate, vanilla, coconut, wood spice, tobacco, molasses and some heat to back it up.  Once again, it really reminds me of chocolate cake batter, with a sticky sweetness and then vanilla, oaky coconut, toffee, burnt sugars, nutty, and a good amount of honey and slightly citrusy sweetness that reminds me of a wheat heavy bourbon. Great layers and just a bit of roasty char on the back end.  Full bodied, slightly sticky but not very slick, somewhat like dark syrup. Lots of that nice oily feel from the barrel at first, then the tannins show up in the finish.  I popped this as a celebration of my first day as a brewer! It lived up to my expectations and was a very satisfying nightcap.

Bottled 9/20/12, poured into a snifter  A- pours pitch black with a small fizzy dark-tan head that reduces quickly leaving no head or lace  S- very complex and pronounced nose. The first thing noticed is straight barrel juice; whiskey with charred oaky barrel with notes of sweet vanilla. Beyond the barrel aroma, dark prune and fig appears with a touch of raw dark chocolate and melted caramel. I can smell this one from a foot away  T- bourbon flavors up front are in your face with juicy barrel flavors, charred oak and vanilla. Semi-dry chocolate comes through mid-palate with toffee and caramel notes. The finish transitions into dark fruity notes of raisin, fig, and prune juice. Dark fruit carries over to the linger with notes of soy sauce and barrel flavor that sits on the palate long after drinking  M- medium-heavy body with low carbonation and a foamy mouthfeel. The finish is smooth, with a big boozy alcohol burn.  O- this beer is big, boozy and packed with bourbon flavors. It's definitely a bourbon drinkers beer, which plays well with my palate. Most bourbon barrel stouts taste like an imperial stout with bourbon notes, this is the opposite, the bourbon flavors take center stage. The only thing that kept this from a 5 own taste is the lingering soy sauce flavor in the finish. Otherwise, a world class beer and one I'd drink again and again

On tap at Urge's 3rd anniversary. Jet black with almost no head. Smells like bourbon, roasted malts alcohol and vanilla. Taste is incredibly strong, lots of bourbon up front with strong vanilla, and alcohol flavors through the middle and back. Ends with a lingering chocolate flavor. LOTS of warming but the alcohol is not overpowering although very clearly present. Very good but I may not have the palette to discern all the more subtle complexities. It is clearly an insanely complex beer that is done very well and tastes great. That being said I've had other imperial stouts I prefer.

Sampled from a 12oz bottle in my DFH snifter. Thanks surge1311!  A - Jet black with a small tan head that dissipates quickly.  S - Loads of bourbon to start. But then it eases up a bit and you get hints of chocolate, coffee, molasses and licorice.  T - Intense! Lots of bourbon. It really dominates yet there's a nice depth of flavor. The roasted malts support it nicely. It hits you hard but it still doesn't seem like 15%.  M - Super creamy with a light airiness from the carbonation that enhances the thickness nicely.  O - This is on the extreme end of the bourbon beer spectrum for me but it works. I'd gladly go back for more.

A: Pours smooth and pitch black with a 1/2 finger of a dark caramel colored head. Head dissipates fairly quickly.  S: Slight alcohol right away but then aromas of coffee, caramel, and chocolate take over quickly. Slight smoky and some dark fruits are also there. The alcohol smell imparts a reminder of anise.  T: Lots of caramel and chocolate. Alcohol is there in flavor but doesn't over power and adds to it. A dark roasted barley flavor comes in the after taste. Flavors linger for a bit of some whiskey.  M: Very thick and coating mouth feel but goes down smooth with very little bite from the alcohol.  O: Very great beer with lots of flavors to appreciate. Vey complex and well done.

Bottle from 2011 aged by a friend who gave this to me as a gift  A- Black, dirty motor oil, minimal to no head  S- Big vanilla notes, bourbon lurking in the background  T- Smooth vanilla up front, followed by lingering caramel and bourbon goodness right behind. Warming alcohol presence throughout.  M- Smooth as can be! Minimal carbonation...  O- Lovely lovely beer here. The aromas alone make this stand out. Aged from 2011, there is no alcohol burn or bite, just smooth sailing all around the palate. The taste is amazing, booziness doesn't overpower here, just keeps inviting you back for more.  Careful when ya drink this...I had one and I was done! Def do not feel it right away, but it sure did creep up on me. :)

A- dark thick black reminiscent of motor oil ... What I would expect from a stout beer of this category  S- bourbon whisky boom.... Really boozy aroma which is perfect if That is your sort of thing (it is for me)  T- really boozy up front that settles nicely into deep dark chocolate  M- Really chewy and thick, this is a big beer that is very full  I have had the 2012 vintage on tap and in th bottle. The alcohol is ramped up in the 2012 vintage that changed the beer slightly that earlier (15% vs 13% ABV) editions. I prefer the slightly less ABV edition but still absolutely Love this version as Well

It's full bodied, deep black, with a smell of bourbon, hints of vanilla, and chocolate. Beautiful strong taste of a mixture of coffee, chocolate and bourbon and goes well with a good piece of steak. This was by far one of the best beers and I would love to find more places that this one. As of now I only know sunset in Allston but if anyone else knows where I can find this in Boston then please share.

2012 Vintage consumed 7/14/13  A - Very near black with a nice finger of chocolate colored head. OK retention and lacing. 4.5  S - Tons of super sweet chocolates and cherry/raisin dark fruits. Vanilla, bourbon and a light but sweet dark fruit aroma 4.75  T - super sweet and alcohol burn initially. The burn ligers but transitions into a vanilla bourbon sweet raisin and cherry flavor which hangs around until the finish and through the aftertaste 4.75  M - full bodied minimal carbonation. very chewy/sticky (more so than BCBCS) 4.75  O - Definitely one of the best biig stouts I've had. Fantastic desert beer/slow sipper. Very sweet 4.75  2013 Vintage consumed 12/9/13 14.9% - I found it to be very similar with a more significant bourbon nose but not flavor.

2012 Edition Bottled 9/20/2012  Appearance: Black, almost no head.  Smell: Chocolate, cherry, dark fruits, some bourbon-like flavors like vanilla. Seriously complex.  Taste: Chocolate again. Rich and boozy. Bourbon. Raisins. Vanilla.  Mouthfeel: Creamy, little carbonation.  Overall: Big, delicious sipper. Do not drink this cold. So many flavors from the bourbon barrel aging come out as it warms.

Update: Drank a cellared 2009 on 11/5/2022. All the flavors remain. If anything a touch more toward old ale/ dried dark fruit. Also there seemed more bitter chocolate in the fudginess. The original barreling in 12yo Elijah Craig barrels remains excellent. Fabulous. The 2009 is 13% and while I didn’t expect any head; the edges of glass have a nice tan halo and glass has quite a bit of residual lacing. Impressed. Nicely surprising is the body remains full and soft; velvety if only a bit bright to the tongue initially as the beer moves a bit warmer and a gets a touch of aeration. Otherwise earlier comments and ratings still hold true. Had considered that beer had peaked earlier, but instead was rewarded with a gentler beer that had even more complexity of flavor. Original review: Been drinking this for years (2009-2017) and thought time to comment. Pretty reliable... one off year/ off bottle. But consistently amazingly complex with malts , hops and barrel. Cold or warm... beer is resplendent with turns of deep stout maltiness; lroasty toasty; Vanilla and caramel; dryness to offset sweetness; black and ruby accents. Fairly lovely head that disappears and doesn’t leave much lacing. Hides the huge ABV and for my taste is as perfect a medium smooth and velvet mouthfeel as you would ever get. For me this is the role model for balance and equity at high altitudes. The fact that they do it every year is a real accomplishment and really deserves the name craft beer as an accolade... not a type of business.

I dont know if it gets any closer to perfect than this beer. WOW!!! Picked up a 4 pack and two singles for the first time in my life last year. Talk about being far from disappointed. I loved how the first thing I tasted was vanilla with a hint of chocolate. The bourbon flavor wasnt overwhelming and the buzz was even better!  The feeling in your mouth was unlike any other, very heavy and full of flavor. The pour was extremely dark with a light brown head!  All I can say still is WOW oh WOW!

Appearance: Says 2012 on the label. Pitch black, with a thin cocoa-colored head that faded quickly. Leaves some lacing and legs as I title the tulip back and forth.  Smell: Lots of bourbon tang, chocolate, alcohol, molasses, more alcohol, faint roasted coffee, and even some vanilla.  Taste: The alcohol is still there (and potent), but the depth of the malty, chocolate and caramel flavors really shine through and to some degree, steal the show from the bourbon and alcohol. Indeed, the bourbon is there and it almost makes the heat completely acceptable. A good bit of residual sweetness, but masked by a firm bitterness and alcohol.  Mouthfeel: Full bodied. Not quite as thick, or chewy as a lot of RIS's are. The bourbon and alcohol almost thin it out slightly. Bitterness lingers into the aftertaste.  Overall: The taste was surprisingly better than the aroma, and the aroma was pretty good to begin with. Perhaps a big excessive on the alcohol, but the bourbon flavors were really kept in check. I think another year or two in the cellar, and this beer would have been magical.

2014 Bottle: 4.5 Brewshare.062715 2014 Bottle: 4.5 Brewshare.040619 2015 Bottle: Nose is the star. So complex smooth and creamy. Not boozy for the ABV. 2017 Bottle: 4.5 Another share 9/27/18 Fudge still so nice. 2018 Draught: 11/23/18 4.5 Big bourbon on this one. Dark chocolate and coffee with subtle vanilla coconut. 2018 Bottle: 11/25/18 Delightful bourbon fudge. Boozy welcomed here.

I have revisited this beer many times since my initial review and decided to finally update what I consider to be a "more accurate" review.  12 oz. Bottle poured into my Duvel Tulip. This is the 2012 vintage.  Appearance: Pitch black with a 1/2" tan head which recedes to a cap, nice lacing.  Smell: Bourbon, still big and bold, draped over a base of coffee and chocolate, oaky vanilla is also present.  Taste: Bourbon, chocolate, toffee, coffee, some vanilla too, and yes maybe a faint hint of licorice. This beer has it all, a big bourbon flavor bomb in a very good way.  Mouth feel: Smooth and creamy and warming.  Overall: Just a really nice BA Stout with so much flavor that the ABV is only noticeable by the warmth in the finish.

Enjoyed at a Goose Island tasting at a local beer distributor.  Poured from tap into a plastic tasting cup. Year 2012  I purchased 4 12oz bottles a month prior so I can age them. Wanted to try It without opening up one of my bottles.  I'm not gonna go into specifics about appearance, mouthfeel and taste as most of the full reviews hit it dead on.  Basically, I had a feeling what the best Bourbon barrel beer should taste like and BCS was that one.... it had everything rolled into one without being overpowering in any aspect.
